name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the statement by the candidate for President of the Commission.  I would remind colleagues that, for this debate, there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no 'blue card' questions will be accepted.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: candidate à la présidence de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, il y a exactement 40 ans, la première Présidente du Parlement européen, Simone Veil, était élue et présentait sa vision d’une Europe plus unie et plus juste. C’est grâce à elle et à toutes les autres icônes européennes que je vous présente aujourd’hui ma vision de l’Europe.  Et 40 ans plus tard, c’est avec une grande fierté que je peux dire: «C’est finalement une femme qui est candidate à la présidence de la Commission européenne.» (Applaudissements) Je le suis grâce à tous ceux et toutes celles qui ont brisé les barrières et les conventions. Je le suis grâce à tous ceux et toutes celles qui ont construit une Europe de paix, une Europe unie, une Europe des valeurs. C’est cette conviction européenne qui m’a guidée tout au long de ma vie et de ma carrière, en tant que mère, en tant que médecin et en tant que femme politique.  C’est ce courage et cette audace des pionnières, comme Simone Veil, qui sont au cœur de ma vision de l’Europe. Et ce sera cet esprit qui guidera la Commission européenne que j’ai l’intention de présider. Herr Präsident, meine Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! Die Gründungsmütter und Gründungsväter Europas haben – aus den Trümmern und der Asche der Weltkriege – ein gewaltiges Werk errichtet: Frieden. Ein starker gemeinsamer Markt, grenzenloser Handel, Reisen, Forschen, Arbeiten. 500 Millionen Europäerinnen und Europäer leben heute zwischen Riga und Limassol, zwischen Athen und Lissabon in Wohlstand und Freiheit. Die Generation meiner Kinder kann sich ein Leben ohne dieses Heimatgefühl Europa gar nicht vorstellen. Als diese glückliche Generation geboren wurde, dachten auch wir Älteren, dass es immer so weiterginge. Heute ist auch den Letzten klar, dass wir wieder kämpfen müssen, dass wir aufstehen müssen für unser Europa. Die ganze Welt ist herausgefordert, mit disruptiven Entwicklungen umzugehen, die auch an Europa nicht vorbeigehen. Der demografische Wandel, die Globalisierung der Weltwirtschaft, die rasante Digitalisierung unserer Arbeitswelt und natürlich der Klimawandel. Keine dieser Meta-Entwicklungen ist neu, sie wurden von der Wissenschaft lange vorausgesagt. Das Neue ist, dass wir heute als Bürgerinnen und Bürger Europas – egal, in welchem Land wir wohnen – die Auswirkungen konkret erleben und spüren. Ob es die finnischen Weizenbauern, die durch die Dürre betroffen sind, ob es die tödliche Hitzewelle in Frankreich ist: Wir spüren den Klimawandel ganz konkret. Ob es die Rentnerin in Irland ist, die mit Online-Banking umgehen muss, oder der Arbeiter in Polen, der sich nach 20 Jahren im Job weiterbilden muss, um überhaupt seine Arbeit zu behalten: Wir spüren die Digitalisierung ganz konkret. Ob es Regionen in Europa sind, in denen Schulen, Krankenhäuser, Betriebe schließen müssen: Wir spüren den demografischen Wandel konkret. All of this has left people with a feeling of losing control: of looser ties with our communities. None of these challenges will go away. But there have been different ways to react to these trends. Some are turning towards authoritarian regimes, some are buying their global influence and creating dependencies by investing in ports and roads. And others are turning towards protectionism. None of these options are for us. We want multilateralism, we want fair trade, we defend the rules-based order because we know it is better for all of us. We have to do it the European way. (Applause) But if we are to go down the European path, we must first rediscover our unity. If we are united on the inside, nobody will divide us from the outside. If we close the gaps between us, we can turn tomorrow’s challenges into tomorrow’s opportunities. Our most pressing challenge is keeping our planet healthy. This is the greatest responsibility and opportunity of our times. I want Europe to become the first climate-neutral continent in the world by 2050. (Applause) To make this happen, we must take bold steps together. Our current goal of reducing our emissions by 40% by 2030 is not enough. We must go further. We must strive for more. A two-step approach is needed to reduce CO2 emissions by 2030 by 50%, if not 55%. The European Union will lead international negotiations to increase the level of ambition of other major economies by 2021 because, to achieve real impact, not only do we have to be ambitious at home – we have to do that, yes – but the world also has to move together. To make this happen, I will put forward a Green Deal for Europe in my first 100 days in office. I will put forward the first ever European Climate Law, which will set the 2050 target in law. This increase in ambition will need investment on a major scale. Public money will not be enough. I will propose a Sustainable Europe Investment Plan and turn parts of the European Investment Bank into a Climate Bank. This will unlock EUR 1 trillion of investment over the next decade. (Applause) It means change. All of us and every sector will have to contribute, from aviation to maritime transport to the way each and every one of us travels and lives. Emissions must have a price that changes our behaviour. To complete this work, and to ensure our companies can compete on a level playing field, I will introduce a Carbon Border Tax to avoid carbon leakage. But what is good for our planet must also be good for our people and our regions. Of course, I know about the importance of cohesion funds. But we need more. We need a just transition for all. Not all of our regions have the same starting point – but we all share the same destination. This is why I will propose a Just Transition Fund to support those most affected. This is the European way: we are ambitious; we leave nobody behind; and we offer perspectives. (Applause) If we want to succeed with this ambitious plan we need a strong economy – because what we want to spend we first have to earn. For that, we need to strengthen the backbone of our economies: the small and medium-sized enterprises. They are innovative, they are entrepreneurial, they are flexible and agile, they create jobs, they provide vocational training to our youth. But they can do all this only if they have access to capital everywhere in this huge single market. Let’s get rid of all the barriers. Let’s open the door. Let’s finally complete the Capital Markets Union. Our small and medium-sized enterprises deserve it. (Applause) And we need to work within the Stability and Growth Pact. Where investment and reforms are needed, we should make sure they can be done. We should make use of all the flexibility allowed in the rules. We are proud of our economy. We want to make it stronger. But there is also a clear and simple logic. It’s not people that serve our economy: it’s the economy that serves our people. (Applause) In our social market economy we must reconcile the market with the social. Therefore, I will refocus our European Semester to make sure we stay on track with our Sustainable Development Goals. And I will stand for fair taxes – whether for brick-and-mortar industries or for digital business. When the tech giants are making huge profits in Europe, this is fine because we are an open market and we like competition. But if they are making these profits by benefiting from our education system, our skilled workers, our infrastructure and our social security, if this is so, it is not acceptable that they make profits but barely pay any taxes because they are playing our tax system. If they want to benefit they have to share the burden. (Applause) Honourable Members, the European way is also about using all of our potential: our people, our talent, our diversity. It is about creating a fairer and more equal Union. This will drive me forward every single day I am in office – as it has throughout my career. We have come a long way since I was a minister for family affairs and had to fight to introduce parental pay or access to childcare for families. But the fight for fairness never stops. It is still too difficult for hard-working families to make ends meet in Europe. I want to ensure that work pays. In a social market economy, every person who is working full time should earn a minimum wage that pays for a decent living. (Applause) Therefore we will develop a framework, of course respecting the different labour markets, but I think the optimal option is to have collective bargaining by employers’ unions and trade unions, because they tailor the minimum wage to the sector or to the region as necessary. Of course, I am aware there are different models, but we have to create the framework.  And I want better protection for those who lose their jobs when our economy takes a severe hit. A European Unemployment Reinsurance Scheme will support our economies and our people in times of external shocks. Of course, there are national unemployment insurance systems, but the Reinsurance Scheme for those heavy external shocks is needed in Europe. I also want more equality and fairness for our young people. Youth unemployment is at 14% in Europe, but ranges from 5% to 40% in some countries. We cannot accept this. Young people have aspirations – they want to work, they want to have a future – and it is our job to let them achieve this. That is why I will make sure that the Youth Guarantee, which I started when I was a Minister for Labour Affairs in the Council, is working as well as it can in every Member State. And I will support the European Parliament’s idea of tripling the Erasmus+ budget as part of the next long-term budget. (Applause) We have to care for the most vulnerable: our children. We have to fight poverty. I know, as a mother of seven, that it makes a difference for their entire life if children have access to education, sports, music, healthy food – and a loving environment. We need a Child Guarantee to help ensure that every child in Europe at risk of poverty and social exclusion has access to the most basic of rights, like healthcare and education. It will empower them and it pays tremendously if we back them when they are young. This is part of my action plan to bring our Pillar of Social Rights to life. And I will start at home by example: I will ensure full gender equality in my College of Commissioners. (Applause) If Member States do not propose enough female Commissioners, I will not hesitate to ask for new names. Since 1958 there have been 183 Commissioners. Only 35 were women. That is less – less – than 20%. We represent half of our population. We want our fair share. (Applause) We also need to talk openly about violence against women. If one in five women have already suffered physical or sexual violence in the European Union, and 55% of women have been sexually harassed, this is clearly not a women’s issue. I will propose to add violence against women to the list of EU crimes defined in the Treaty, and the European Union should join the Istanbul Convention. I am convinced: if we close the gaps between us, we will emerge stronger as a Union. (Applause) The cradle of our European civilisation is Greek philosophy and Roman law. And our European continent went through its darkest period when we were ruled by dictators and the rule of law was banished. For centuries, Europeans fought so hard for their liberty and independence. The rule of law is our best tool to defend these freedoms and to protect the most vulnerable in our Union. That is why there can be no compromise when it comes to respecting the rule of law. There never will be. (Applause) I will ensure that we use our full and comprehensive toolbox at European level. In addition, I fully support an EU-wide Rule of Law Mechanism. And to be clear: the new instrument is not an alternative to the existing instruments, but an additional one. The Commission will always be an independent guardian of the Treaties. Lady Justice is blind – she will defend the rule of law wherever it is attacked.  Honourable Members, the rule of law is universal. It applies to all. In the last five years, more than 17 000 people have drowned in the Mediterranean, which has become one of the deadliest borders in the world. At sea, there is the duty to save lives … (Loud applause) … and in our treaties and conventions there is the legal and moral duty to respect the dignity of every human being. The European Union can and must defend these values. The European Union needs humane borders. We must save, but saving alone is not enough. We must reduce irregular migration and we must fight smugglers and traffickers: it is organised crime. We must preserve the right to asylum and improve the situation of refugees: for example, through humanitarian corridors in close cooperation with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. We need both empathy and decisive action. I am aware of how difficult and divisive discussions on these issue are. We need to address the legitimate concerns of many, and to look at how we can overcome our differences. I will propose a New Pact on Migration and Asylum, including the relaunch of the Dublin reform. This will allow us to return to a fully functioning Schengen Area of free movement, the key driver of our prosperity, security and freedoms. A centrepiece in this ambition is a reinforced European Border and Coast Guard Agency. We need to reach a standing corps of 10 000 Frontex border guards not by 2027, but way earlier, at least by 2024. We have to modernise our asylum system. A Common European Asylum System must be exactly that – common. We can have stable external borders only if we give enough help to Member States facing the most pressure because of where they are on the map. We need solidarity. We need to help each other and to contribute. We need a new way of burden sharing. And we must make a fair cooperation offer to countries of origin and transit, in the interest of both sides. Diplomacy, economic development, investment, stability and security are needed so that people have a perspective. I would like to tell you a story about perspective. Four years ago, I was lucky enough to welcome a 19-year-old refugee from Syria into my home and my family. He spoke no German, he was deeply scarred by his experience of civil war and flight. Today, four years later, he is fluent in German, he is fluent in English and, of course, he is fluent in Arabic. He is a community leader by day, in vocational training, and a student for his high school degree by night. He is an inspiration to us all. And one day, he wants to go home. Honourable Members, as a defence minister, I have been many times in this war-torn neighbourhood. I will never forget the words of former President of Iraq Fuad Masum, who said: ‘We want to see more Europe here.’ The world is calling for more Europe. The world needs more Europe. I believe Europe should have a stronger and more united voice in the world – and it needs to act fast. That is why we must have the courage to take foreign policy decisions by qualified majority, and to stand united behind them. (Loud applause. Mixed reactions) The cornerstone of our collective defence will always be NATO. We will stay transatlantic, and we have to become more European. That is why we created the European Defence Union. Our work for our European Union of security and defence is embedded in comprehensive security. Stabilisation always comes with diplomacy, reconciliation and reconstruction. Our servicemen and servicewomen work side by side with police officers, diplomats and development aid workers. These men and women deserve our utmost respect and recognition for their tireless service for Europe. (Applause) I cannot talk about Europe without talking about our friends from the United Kingdom. In 2016, for the very first time, a Member State decided to leave the European Union. (Applause from a section of the House) This is a serious decision. We regret it, but we respect it. Since then, together with the current Government of the United Kingdom, the European Union has worked hard to organise the orderly departure of the United Kingdom. The Withdrawal Agreement concluded with the Government of the United Kingdom provides certainty where Brexit created uncertainty: in preserving the rights of citizens and in preserving peace and stability on the island of Ireland. These two priorities are mine, too. However, I stand ready for a further extension of the withdrawal date, should more time be required for a good reason. (Applause. Objections) In any case, the United Kingdom will remain our ally, our partner and our friend. (Applause) Honourable Members, when I came to Strasburg 13 days ago, I promised I’d come to listen. I have heard your concerns, your hopes and your expectations. The political guidelines, which I sent to you today, reflect our discussions. From what I have heard, I have drawn my conclusions and I have made my decisions. First, I want European citizens to play a leading and active part in building the future of our Union. I want them to have their say at a Conference on the Future of Europe, to start in 2020 and to run for two years.  Second, I want us to work together to improve the Spitzenkandidaten system. We need to make it more visible to a wider electorate and we need to address the issue of transnational lists at the European elections as a complementary tool of European democracy. (Applause) And third – yes – I support a right of initiative for the European Parliament.  (Loud applause) When this House, acting by majority of its Members, adopts resolutions requesting the Commission to submit legislative proposals, I commit to responding with a legislative act in full observance of the proportionality, subsidiarity and better-law-making principles. I am convinced that our stronger partnership will further help to make people’s voices heard. Herr Präsident, mein Vater war 15 Jahre alt, als der schaurige Krieg, durch den mein Land Tod, Verwüstung, Vertreibung und Zerstörung über unseren Kontinent gebracht hat, endete. Er hat seinen Kindern, mir und meinen sechs Geschwistern, oft davon erzählt. Er hat vor allem davon erzählt, was es für ihn bedeutet hat, dass die anderen Länder uns wieder die Hand gereicht haben und uns zurückgenommen haben in den Kreis der demokratischen Völker. Er hat bei der Montan-Union angefangen und hat uns anfangs gesagt: „Wir treiben wieder Handel und wenn man Handel treibt, dann schließt man Freundschaften, und Freunde schießen nicht aufeinander.“ Er war Kabinettschef bei von der Groeben in der Hallstein-Kommission und später Generaldirektor für Wettbewerbsfragen. Deshalb bin ich hier in Brüssel geboren und Europäerin gewesen, bevor ich später gelernt habe, dass ich Deutsche bin und Niedersächsin bin. Und deshalb gibt es für mich nur eines: Europa einen und stärken. Wer mit mir dieses Europa stärken, wachsen und blühen lassen will, hat mich als leidenschaftliche Kämpferin an seiner oder ihrer Seite. Wer aber dieses Europa schwächen, spalten und ihm seine Werte nehmen will, der findet in mir eine erbitterte Gegnerin. (Beifall) Als mein Vater alt und an seinem Lebensende war, da hatte sich seine Erzählung von Europa verändert. Er sprach nicht mehr so viel vom Krieg. Er sagte: „Europa ist wie eine lange Ehe. Die Liebe wird vielleicht nicht größer als am ersten Tag, aber sie wird tiefer“. Weil wir wissen, dass wir uns aufeinander verlassen können, in guten wie in schweren Zeiten. Weil wir wissen, dass wir streiten können, aber uns auch wieder versöhnen können. Weil wir nie vergessen, warum wir diesen Bund eingegangen sind. Und wir hier alle in diesem Raum leben in einem Europa, das gewachsen ist, das gereift ist, das stark geworden ist mit seinen 500 Millionen Menschen. Über 200 Millionen Menschen sind zur Wahl gegangen. Dieses Europa hat Einfluss. Dieses Europa will Verantwortung übernehmen für sich und diese Welt.  Das ist nicht immer leicht, das weiß ich, das ist schmerzhaft und anstrengend, aber es ist unsere nobelste Pflicht! Die Menschen wollen sehen, dass wir liefern, dass wir vorankommen. Die Jugend fordert das. Meine Kinder sagen mir zurecht: „Spielt nicht auf Zeit, macht was draus“. Und dazu bin ich angetreten. Dazu brauche ich Ihre Hilfe und Unterstützung. Dazu rufe ich alle Europäerinnen und Europäer auf, mitzumachen. Es ist das Kostbarste, was wir haben: Es lebe Europa, vive l’Europe, long live Europe!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Following the election of our President two weeks ago, the election of the President of the European Commission is now on the agenda. I would like to thank Ursula von der Leyen for her programme, for her ideas, for her proposals for the future of Europe. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, our election promises are at the heart of the agenda. The promises we have made to the people are a point of reference for us. 40 million people have been elected by the 183 Members of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. We are committed to these 40 million people, and they expect us to implement the issues we have promised them: a just Europe with comparable living conditions for all, a modern Europe where we remain or must become the research department of the world, a secure Europe that secures borders against illegal migration and at the same time helps people in need, a europe open to the world, a europe open to the world. , trade and partnership with Africa, and an ecological Europe that protects our environment, our climate while keeping an eye on social and economic consequences. Ursula von der Leyen is a Christian Democrat, she is a convinced European, and that is why we will work with her to implement our election promises. The European People's Party will support and vote for Ursula von der Leyen today. I would like to thank Frans Timmermans, Ska Keller, Bas Eickhout and others for their dedicated campaigning at European level. I enjoyed the contest of being a candidate, showing face, accepting the contest, fighting for his convictions objectively, convincing people and then respecting the election result as a Democrat. 201 million people took part in the European elections – what a celebration of democracy! And their desire is to have a democratic Europe.  Developments in recent days have not always taken up this strong sign of people. If, for example, we designate democratic nominees as unelectable out of party political egoisms, thereisabout damage to democracy. Damage has been done, yes, but you cannot heal damage done by dealing new damage. Europe now needs capacity for action and stability. That is why, two weeks ago, my group supported the Socialist candidate David Sassoli as President of the European Parliament, and I expect today, as group chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, to support Ursula von der Leyen as President of the Commission. I say today that we must be able to rely on each other, and that is the only way that Europe can succeed. (Applause) Of course, over the next five years, we must be committed to a democratic Europe: a right of legislative initiative – thank you for the commitment – strengthened investigative rights, better control of the implementation of European law and the legal anchoring of the leading candidate concept, so that the backrooms are finally a thing of the past. I and my group will be in favour of a Europe that belongs to the people. For us Christian Democrats, today is a day of departure. We now want to tackle and shape, with Ursula von der Leyen as the new President of the Commission. (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, Mrs von der Leyen, today is an important day, of those who make history. The future of the Union is in our hands. And my political group, which has been in its DNA since the beginning and has Europeanism in its DNA, wants to continue to build this Europe of ours. We have a responsibility to the citizens who have given us their trust and that is why we want to act with responsibility. We want to make sure that, over the next five years, we will lay the foundations for a project and a sustainable future for all Europeans and Europeans. Let me, on a day like today, remind a great Europeanist who, just forty years ago, took the floor in this Parliament: Willy Brandt. In that plenary session, held just after the first direct elections in 1979, he appealed that is now worth remembering. He lamented how slowly European democracy was advancing and that it had taken too long to implement the direct suffrage elections. He also lamented that the European institutions still seemed far removed from citizenship. That is why he called on MEPs to be able to get to work, beyond ideological and geographical differences, to solve people's problems and, above all, to connect with young people. Forty years later, this speech is more alive than ever. It still seems to the Socialists that European democracy is moving too slowly. We have put a lot of enthusiasm into the Spitzenkandidat project and we have also been beaten by transnational lists. But on this occasion we haven't made it. However, we do not give up. European democracy has no turning back. That is why we welcome your commitment, Mrs von der Leyen, to resume and refine the Spitzenkandidat process by 2024. We also want Europe to solve people's problems, who are able to meet today's challenges. And we need to know that before we give it our support to chair the Commission. We need to know if he will be able to lead the change that citizens are asking of us and the transformation that young Europeans are asking of us. You have sent us a letter pointing in the right direction, which proposes progress, but now you have the possibility to make even more concrete. You assume the objective of combating climate urgency and translating that ambition into legislation. This law is necessary, as well as setting binding targets to meet our emission reduction commitments by 2030. But, in addition to ecological transformation, it is essential for us that no one is left behind and, therefore, we are pleased to see that you accept the substance for a just transition. It also reflects the need to implement an investment plan for a sustainable Europe. It is important to make it clear that a significant part of that effort must come from public investment. When we ask to introduce the sustainable development goals in the European Semester, we do not just want them to be considered as a principle. We also want measurement criteria and indicators to be introduced. We do not want governments that invest in an economic transformation that cares for people, creates new opportunities and lays the foundations for a sustainable future with excessive deficits. That is why we insist — and you have also included this in your letter — on the flexibility of economic rules and on the incorporation of unemployment insurance. Europe has to protect the most vulnerable. That is why we will always support from our political group the European social pillar and, in particular, the Children's Guarantee and the Youth Guarantee. Mrs von der Leyen, we need stronger action against poverty in general. To finance all these policies, everyone must do their part, including large technology corporations. You want them to contribute their taxes to the common effort, but have you thought of a figure? It also mentions that the situation of workers on the new platforms should be protected and improved. Here you will have a political group that will support a directive in that regard. I am pleased to see that, on issues of gender equality, we are on the same page. Because you know that, for my political group, it's a clear priority. Adopting a binding equality strategy and including gender-based violence as one of the offences covered by the Treaties of the Union is undoubtedly a good start. He says he will defend the rule of law and proposes a new mechanism to ensure compliance. Can you explain to us what this mechanism would consist of? I believe that many and many in this room would be reassured to see that, indeed, you intend to maintain the demand shown by the current Commission and, in particular, Commissioner Frans Timmermans on rule of law. With regard to migration management, we appreciate your proposal to act more in solidarity between member states and to end Dublin's reform. We need to talk about solidarity. We need to talk about humanitarian corridors. It's not just about strengthening security and increasing Frontex's troops. It is also about saving people's lives and, for that, we need a rescue system that does not criminalize NGOs and a humanitarian visa system. Only then will we live up to the circumstances. Mrs. von der Leyen, we're here to listen to you. We do not want an institutional crisis that further delayed the changes Europe needs. But we need assurances that, in the coming years, Europe will be able to cope with the necessary measures. My political group will make a decision this afternoon. Have no doubt that you will do so with Europe in the best of life in need of men and women who want to regain confidence and hope in the European project. And, on that path, we will find ourselves in the exciting task of building Europe more and better.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President-elect, the Parliament before you today has never been so important and involved, aware of responsibility and ready to fully assume it.  You know very well, the Council that appointed you is a divided Council. Finally agreed on a comprehensive package of appointments to achieve a compromise after long and difficult negotiations. Moreover, I regret that the balance between the east and west of the European Union is not reflected in this package, and I hope, however, that it will be partially restored with the allocation of important portfolios in the future college. Today, here, there is no package. There is only one nomination – yours – based on the commitments you have made before us. Today, we are looking for a majority that will enable Europe to move forward and meet the very clear expectations expressed during the elections.  The idea of Spitzenkandidat – to elect the President of the European Commission by the vote of all European citizens – has not been carried out. This Parliament will have to do so by the end of this mandate, and I am glad that you are taking on the idea of a conference for the future of Europe, which will complete this process of democratisation. Europeans need to know that in these last days, the negotiation carried out with you by pro-European political groups has been based on a common political platform of these groups. If elected, this platform should provide us with a common and transparent framework between Parliament and the European Commission, with clearly assumed objectives for the next 5 years.  Our group is ready to support you, insofar as you assume independence and the force of proposal for the renewal of Europe. The clearer the commitments you are making today and are shared by a strong pro-European majority, the more we will be able to build a Europe for European citizens that restores confidence and hope. Before the elections, a great anti-European wave was announced, which would have overwhelmed this Parliament and put Europe in great difficulty. Well, this tsunami has not occurred, and pro-European forces are strong in this new Parliament. But we must no longer disappoint the millions of Europeans who have said 'yes' to this Europe. They expect it to defend the rule of law without hesitation. We cannot disappoint the millions of young people who have come to vote and called for the fight against climate change, for decent jobs for their generation. We must not disappoint millions of entrepreneurs, employees and farmers, who expect Europe to become a real opportunity in an open world, a Europe that builds an economy for people, able to integrate ecology, climate balance, sustainability, but also new technologies and digital strategy, as opportunities and not constraints. The internal market must be taken out of the logic of numbers and bureaucracy and generate wealth for people.  But above all, we expect from you, Mrs Ursula von der Leyen, a real European and pro-European leadership. Europe is not just an administration, but it is primarily a political ambition, an ambition of citizens. If you are confirmed by this Parliament, which I want you, you will often hear explanations and arguments around you that convince you that many changes are not possible, and yet you will have to make them possible.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, our common house is burning. It is burning with a dying climate, collapsing biodiversity and depleted natural resources. It burns with ever deeper inequalities, fuelled by neoliberal globalization and technological revolutions. It burns with a sudden, or sometimes more devious, retreat from fundamental freedoms and the rule of law.  In the face of this triple emergency, goodwill and general intentions are not enough. We need a fierce determination to change course, even if it means offending head-on the interests of those who defend the status quo. This is our determination and it is on such a mandate for change that the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance was elected in May.  So here you are today in front of us, Mrs von der Leyen. Just three weeks ago, you had no idea that you would run for the highest office in the European Union. That's not to say that learning must have been fast.  Your performances last week did not convince us of your sense of urgency, nor of your determination to reorient the Union's policies. By comparison, the speech you have just given and the accompanying writings are a clear step forward. I welcome your plea, supported by concrete measures, for equality between women and men.  I also note that you are personally in favour of halving our CO2 emissions by 2030, that you are taking up the idea of a carbon tax at the borders or that of European unemployment reinsurance, all of which are taboo ideas in the political family from which you come; I salute your courage in this regard. But if your speech is more concrete today, it falls well short of our expectations. Let me explain why based on a few examples. Why, for example, raise our climate targets in two stages in the face of urgency, and not immediately? In fact, when you read the detail of what you write to two political groups, you feel this idea of conditionality. In other words, we will move forward when others are ready to move forward as well. You rightly point out that the ecological transition should not leave anyone at the side of the road. However, you cannot ignore that if the price of carbon rises, everyone - and, in particular, the most insecure - will be affected.  The answer to this is not, as you suggest, a European Adjustment Fund, but rather a profound revision of our taxation so that it finally becomes fair again. The environment is not just about the climate. Not a word from you about biodiversity or the depletion of resources such as arable land or fresh water. In these areas, the Common Agricultural Policy, the EU's first budget, has a disastrous impact. A Copernican revolution is therefore necessary, but it remains taboo for you. Would the great ambitions be shattered by the well-understood interests of some? Let's move on to free trade treaties. In their present form, they are cardinal instruments of a globalization that, at the same time, exhausts the planet and exacerbates inequalities. You are in favour of these treaties including, as they already do, sustainable development clauses, but you cautiously refrain from committing to these clauses being binding and punishable. Nor is there a word about the preferential treatment that continues to be reserved for so-called investors.  On the issue of asylum and migration, I have not really heard you question the 'fortress Europe' scandal. It is shameful and undignified that the Union relies on authoritarian regimes or failed states to ensure the sealing of its borders at all costs. And this at the cost of massive human rights violations, sometimes committed by armed gangs such as these famous Libyan coastguards, financed with European money. You are proposing a new pact on asylum and migration. Mrs von der Leyen, this pact exists. It was adopted by a majority of five political groups by this Parliament. Don't reinvent the wheel! Take it over and go fight the Council!  Finally, on the rule of law, your language is all the stronger because your proposals remain relatively vague. Is it a question of changing the situation and ensuring that European values are respected everywhere and at all times, or, on the contrary, of sparing those Heads of State and Government who, within the Union itself, as in Hungary and Poland, regularly flout fundamental freedoms and the separation of powers?  In short, where a change of course is required to the extent of the triple social, environmental and democratic emergency, you propose here a inflection, there incremental changes and, above all, a lot of blur.  You will understand that, under these conditions, the environmentalists are not ready today to entrust you with the helm of the Union.  Dear Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to point out that since the elections, the Greens/European Free Alliance group has spared no effort to form a majority here that is both pro-European and pro-change. Such a venture takes time to bear fruit. Your insistence on a vote today deprives us of that time.  While we welcome your courtesy to us, we have not felt any real preference for such an alliance on your part. On the contrary, we feel ready to welcome any support from wherever it comes, including populist national ranks. We cannot do that. But, as I told you a week ago, the sale starts when the customer says no.  If you were to be elected tonight, rest assured that we will be prepared to be persuaded and to assist whenever your proposals are up to the social, environmental and democratic emergency, in other words, to meet the existential challenges we face.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, Minister von der Leyen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for her work. We have a very important and exposed personnel decision to make today in this House. The office of President of the European Commission is of great importance to the Union and its Member States. That is why this decision is to be taken with great care. Only one person of the highest suitability can be eligible for this position. Minister von der Leyen, with all due respect to you, we in the Identity and Democracy Group, after careful consideration, believe that you are not up to the demands of this office. I would like to explain this briefly: firstly, we Germans have our own experience with your way of running and shaping policy. Over the years, we have seen you in Germany as Minister for Family Affairs, as Minister for Labour and Social Affairs, and finally as Minister for Defence. In none of these offices have you satisfactorily fulfilled your task of serving the good of the German people. I am saving you and the auditorium here an explicit list of your failure. They have destroyed our squad. Today it is as miserable as it has never been equipped and practically incapable of defence. There will be a great breath of fresh air in the Bundeswehr when you resign as Minister of Defence tomorrow, regardless of the outcome of today. A complete reboot in virtually all areas will be needed here.  Now, German governments in the past have often placed politicians who have become unpopular in Brussels posts. But that can no longer be the claim here and now. From our point of view, there is nothing to suggest that you would fill the position of the Commission Presidency better than your previous posts. Your presentation tour through the House and its political groups, your long list of cloudy promises of this and that, and usually also of its opposite, depending on where they were presented, was by no means only critical of us. You assure the left and liberals that you want to stick strictly to the Article 7 procedure against Poland and Hungary. In the ECR Group, you agree to mild rules of law and tolerance in the distribution of migrants. These contradictions are glaring. And today you serve here an incredible bouquet of well-sounding keywords. There should be something for everyone that they like to hear. Here in your candidacy tour, you show a classic mainstream political behavior, make empty promises, play a kind of Jekyll and Hyde with the factions in the fearful hope that somehow enough votes for your election will be able to generate in the end. Their problem with all this is that they lack any convincing vision of a modern Union of the fatherlands that truly serves the people of the Union, wisely and sensibly limited to its core tasks. On the contrary, they promise even more centralisation, even more taxation, even more paternalism, even more presumption of competence and completely contradictory content. They are still afflicted with the old thinking, but obviously do not feel it. Of the questions I asked you last week in the Conference of Presidents on my group, you did not answer two at all and the third answered very unsatisfactory. You cannot convince us of the ID Group with such a socialist performance, as we have said here today. We shall therefore vote against you. (Applause)

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened to you very carefully, Mrs von der Leyen, I also did so at our group meeting, and I have to say that, in your speech today, positions have changed quite much compared to what we heard last week. Because a person who is under investigation in our country for ramming a Guardia di Finanza ship, failing to comply with the orders of the national authorities and risking the death of Italian law enforcement officers in this Parliament, was the subject of a debate in the LIBE Committee last week in order to be able to invite her to a hearing. name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to thank mrs von der Leyen for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There has been a lot of talk about European citizens, and I have received hundreds, if not thousands, of e-mails in the last few days, as probably many other Members, who are dealing with your nomination. I would like to take this opportunity to give the floor to the European demos here, by quote from one of these e-mails. It says: 'As a voter, I expect Parliament to elect one of the leading candidates as President of the European Commission'. And the lady, from whose e-mail I am currently citing, then continues: "In my view, the appointment of a Defence Minister as President of the Commission would be a decision with a fatal signal that the EU is taking a course towards militarisation and isolation." I do not think there is anything to add to the criticism of your nomination or to the content. I would like to refer to the meeting we had last week. You were in the Left Group and presented your idea, your vision of the European future, and it has become clear that our vision is different. I would also like to justify this at this point. We are the only group in this House who are united in our opposition to the continuation of austerity. And if someone like you, who, like you, talks about the future of Europe, I believe that he must finally break with this false neoliberal ideology. Austerity has not led, for example, to the rebuilding of state budgets, but, on the contrary, it has only meant that public investment could no longer be made, for example, that there was no longer any investment in education, that no more investment was made in health protection, and also that there were no resources available to fight decisively against climate change. The victims of this policy are the citizens throughout the European Union. Mrs von der Leyen, anyone who wants to combat the climate emergency must act now, and anyone who wants to cope with economic structural change must invest now, and anyone who wants to guarantee social security in the European Union must now break with this false austerity policy. 113 million people – these are official figures from the Commission – live in poverty or are affected by poverty in the European Union, and I expect more than flowery words from a Candidate for the Presidency of the Commission. I expect you to stand here and say: yes, I understand that we need a social offensive for the European Union. My aim is that in five years' time, no European citizen, no matter what age, in which region, will be affected by a need for livelihoods, but will be able to live a dignified life.  This, of course, requires the financial conditions. Unfortunately, however, in the area of tax policy, you have remained very vague today. I tell you that velvet gloves are the wrong tool to ensure tax justice. I expect a candidate for the Presidency of the Commission to have the firm will and courage to engage with the corporations and to say quite clearly here: yes, I want to put an end to tax dumping, I want to close the tax havens in the European Union too, and I want to finally share corporations and assets fairly in the tax revenue and ensure tax justice. (Applause) Billions more are now to be invested in the armament of the European Union. You have made that clear once again. So that is money that will be lacking, for example, for social security, health, education, etc., and that will not go to public services of general interest, but, for example, to modern weapons systems. Some people even dream of a space army these days. I think, to be honest, this is more of a nightmare. But whether you are talking about a European army or an army of Europeans, that is, for me, a word-of-the-word thing. After all, the objective is quite clear: the result is an armament of the European Union and a militarisation of foreign policy. As a left-wing group in the European Parliament, we are firmly opposed to this. We call for an EU strategy to strengthen diplomatic conflict resolution. In our view, a first step would be to convene an international conference on disarmament. I would like to mention one last point. Europe's external borders are currently the deadliest borders in the world. I think it is a political declaration of bankruptcy of European policy that people have to die every day in the Mediterranean, while those who defend universal human rights are being criminalised in some Member States. Mrs von der Leyen, I have listened very carefully to what you said earlier. As a left-wing group, we will pay close attention to the policy you are trying to implement. However, I think that our plan – and this has become clear – for the future of the European Union, a social European Union, a climate-friendly European Union and a peaceful European Union, is not compatible with your vision. That is why, unfortunately, we will not be able to vote for you today.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Mr President, I may be speaking from the back of the chamber today but, as I predicted last time I was here, in the European elections the Brexit Party were very much to the front of the elections and massive, massive winners. I come back to a place that has been humbled and humiliated.  The European Council stitch—up has rendered this place impotent, until today when you’ve got some real power if you choose to use it. What you’ve seen from Ursula von der Leyen today is an attempt for the European Union to take control of every single aspect of our lives. She wants to build a centralised, undemocratic, updated form of communism, where the state controls everything and nation-state parliaments will cease to have any relevance at all. I have to say, from our perspective, that in some ways I’m really rather pleased, because you’ve just made Brexit a lot more popular in the United Kingdom. Thank God we’re leaving. But it is in the aspects of defence that, I think, people’s minds should be focused. She’s a fanatic for building a European army, but she’s not alone. When it’s completed, NATO will cease to exist or have any relevance in Europe at all. And, not to be left out of this, French President, Emmanuel Macron, on Bastille Day last Sunday, stood at the front of an open-top car with his nascent European defence force behind him looking for all the world like an updated version of Napoleon. Be in no doubt. Five years of these people and the European defence union will be complete. What is there for defence can also be used for attack. You, as a House, will have no control over it. Vote against this nominee. Strike a blow for democracy. Strike a blow for your citizens. Do it today.

These are all tasks that we want to accomplish together, and that is why I have of great interest. name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs von der Leyen, your appointment is the result of a difficult stalemate which has seen the European Council unable to find the required majority for any of the Spitzenkandidaten. It is a possibility provided for in the rules and yet, politically and institutionally, it is a wound that needs to be remedied so as not to put a stop to the process of building a true European democracy.  That is why it is important that our group – and others too – have entered into political and programmatic negotiations with you, tying our support to specific commitments. This is a significant innovation which can strengthen the relationship between the citizens and Europe and which must be taken seriously by everyone, starting with the Council, otherwise the damage to credibility will be incalculable.  In your letter to our group and in your fine speech, you have responded positively to many of our requests. More ambitious environmental objectives, investment plan for sustainability which – I am precise – requires more public investment, more public investment, full use of flexibility to ensure support for growth, European scheme for the reinsurance of unemployment benefits, minimum wage, European guarantee against child poverty, common consolidated basis for corporate taxation, defence of the rule of law, humanitarian corridors , a new pact for migration and asylum based on solidarity, and then, at institutional level, Parliament's right of initiative, the transition to the Community method in crucial areas, the strengthening of the Spitzenkandidaten system. We appreciate these commitments and will fight with determination for their full implementation. It seems clear to me from your letter and from the debate – and this is a good thing – that the political interlocutors of the new Commission are and will be the pro-European forces, and we will never accept any ambiguity in this regard. It seems to me that it is clear – and this is good for Europe – that nationalist sovereignists are and will be irrelevant.  Mrs von der Leyen, our group will be an attentive and demanding interlocutor. We are not satisfied with words. If these words are not followed up by deeds, you will no longer have our support. If, on the contrary, the commitments we have asked of you are reaffirmed and put into practice, you will be able to count on our loyal, vigilant and combative contribution to a better, more united and fairer Europe.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I have only one minute; also, I will be brief and I will go straight to the point. We, the French delegation and our group, will give you our support at 6 p.m. so that you have a fairly large majority of pro-Europeans in this Chamber during the election for the presidency of the Commission.  We had a rather special election, with nationalists predicting that they would have a majority in this Chamber, where today there is a majority of pro-Europeans of all stripes ready to support a number of proposals that you have put forward.  We have found in your project several proposals that we are involved in: the climate bank, in particular, carbon neutrality, the issue of the carbon tax and the minimum wage, all of which are important for a number of political groups, particularly among the pro-Europeans in this Chamber. More needs to be done, particularly on trade agreements, and to make all trade agreements subject to the Paris Agreement - at the initiative of the Commission, possibly. I would also like to send a message to the Greens in particular, because if we have a majority of pro-Europeans in this Chamber, we also need all the pro-Europeans on this project. Those who tell us every day that the climate emergency is the most important are right. Those who tell us that this issue must be dealt with in this Chamber, because it is european in scope, even global, must also, in view of your statements and your proposals, be at the rendezvous of history.  This is the first time that we have such proposals, at least such an environmental commitment, in this Chamber. We need a majority of pro-Europeans around your candidacy. Therefore, I call for accountability and commitment around you and a majority of pro-Europeans for this Commission.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister von der Leyen, you have offered us a Green Deal, but there is a green headline on it in this deal, but little green content. Our world is facing two major ecological crises: the climate crisis and the crisis of species extinction. On the climate crisis, this Parliament has made it clear that we must deliver minus 55% by 2030. You have not made it clear today that you are fully committed to this objective. However, this is the yardstick that the people – the young people on the streets of Europe – are right to demand and that science demands of us. We need a clear commitment minus 55% greenhouse gases by 2030. (Applause) And the second is species extinction. They have lived relevant parts of their lives in Hanover, where I counted butterflies and dragonflies. The animals I counted in the Hanoverian region at the time are no longer there. You have said nothing about the biodiversity crisis. We are clearly calling for a new European agricultural policy that protects farmers and puts an end to species extinction. Today, commit yourself to presenting a new European agricultural policy that protects the climate and, ecologically, finally sends a signal against the rampant extinction of species. Finally, I would like to say one more thing: at Europe's external borders, it is not enough to mourn the death in the Mediterranean. The question for you is: are you prepared to set up a European maritime rescue mission and provide Frontex with a robust mandate to stop dying? Her speech was good. Their content wasn't good enough.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr von der Leyen, your speech was a speech that did not surprise us. It was a speech that we have heard several times in this House, full of promises that you too know you will not be able to keep. Your path will be a difficult one, as we have seen in recent days and we have seen it in the debate in this House.  It will have to balance two parts and two very divergent interests, those of the right that wants a Europe that controls immigration more strongly, that wants a realistic and pragmatic approach to climate, that supports the economy, growth, industry and work, and that of a left that has an ideological approach, that has an indiscriminate welcoming approach, that has a Taliban approach on the climate issue , and that will be the big problem with your mandate. It is from a centre-right politician to decide whether he wants to give in to the blackmail of the left, as he seemed to want to do in his letters of reply to the Socialists and Liberals, or as it has seemed in many places in your speech today to have a pragmatic approach that will really enable Europe to get out of the mud where this approach has led it, from the crisis, where the wrong policies have led it. , from an endless crisis.  Here you spoke of welcoming, of saving lives at sea, in short, all beautiful, but I did not see much emphasis in your speech on the millions of Europeans who have suffered and still suffer from the wrong policies made by this majority. I have not heard a word about the combined disaster in Greece and the fact that that country has been destroyed by the policies that Europe wanted to impose, so it does not seem that you do not have the will, nor do you have a majority ready to bring about the radical change that the citizens of Europe asked us to make in the vote on 26 May. Radicalizing or excluding the ideas of those who think differently will not help Europe to grow, it will not help you to govern, it will not really help this Parliament to establish supremacy or an important path for the next five years. We do not believe that you can represent the change that is necessary and we do not believe that you will have an easy life in maintaining a majority that makes water on all sides and that looks like a sieve.  I say, once again, that the votes of those on this side of the House will count, that no one on this side of the House has offered support for the election of the President, but it was a request that came precisely in the knowledge that this Parliament and this legislature cannot move to the left and in the knowledge that those who sit in this group will count in the next five years to shift the balance.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Ms von der Leyen that in politics, in this House, we understand that you sometimes need to create a majority, but what is always important is what kind of promises you give and how far you go with those promises. Like a chef in a huge restaurant, you are responsible for the ingredients which you will put in a baked pie, what the taste of this pie will be and how satisfied customers will be. After five years, a majority of citizens, in Riga or in a small village in the west of Portugal, should be able to say that this is a good result.  I don’t think this will be the case. Why? Last week, you came to our Group and you said that one that one of the key principles is subsidiarity. Today, I calculated that the first time you said this was after 30 minutes. I don’t think that transnational lists will become closer to the hearts of citizens; I don’t think that a qualified majority vote can decide everything and be good for everybody. And where are the rights of minorities on the political scene, or proportionality? So, sorry, but it is a bit disappointing today compared with last week.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Madam von der Leyen, you represent the consensus that has been determining the direction of the European Union for decades. The consensus of inequalities between countries in which the surpluses of one are built upon the deficits and sacrifices of others. The consensus of precariousness, instability in the lives of millions of workers, unemployment and underemployment, inequality between men and women. The consensus of large capital, which sacrifices the environment and social rights for the profits of multinationals. The consensus of privatizations and the attack on public services. The consensus of militarism and war.  Well, the Europe of progress, social justice, environmental protection, the Europe of democracy, solidarity, cooperation and peace, this other Europe will not be born of this consensus and it is therefore that, for its election, it will count on the same as always. It will not count on those fighting for this other Europe and, I assure you, that this fight will continue in the coming years.

name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Dear Mrs von der Leyen, welcome! I am very pleased that I am no longer the most frivolous representative of European democracy. The staff table presented by the Council has it all: Josep Borell – a Spanish type who had to resign as President of the European University Institute because he forgot to mention an annual gratuity of EUR 300 000 – is supposed to represent European values in the world as external representative. Christine Lagarde – a lawyer who was found guilty of embezzling 400 million euros of public money and has never run a national central bank – is to lead the ECB. Charles Michel – a Belgian who could not even form a functioning government in Belgium – is to become President-in-Office of the Council and ensure that the interests of national interests are balanced in an increasingly complex web of national interests, and you, Mrs von der Leyen, a German minister who is completely knowledgeable in Terms of European policy and who has only been noticed by a mad penchant for overpriced advisers, mismanagement and euphemisms, such as 'trend-turning finances' for the largest German rearmament campaign since the end of the war. In order to secure this parade of incompetence and moral sausages, are you making a pact with the illiberal PiS party as well as the would-be fascists Orban and Benito Salvini? We should not leave Europe to the laymen – wink smiley.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: – Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to summarise the position of the Hungarian national delegation of the People's Party in three points.  Firstly, the new President of the European Commission will only do the right thing if he does everything possible to protect the Union's external borders. Immigration must be stopped and this is the only way to stop it. The mass illegal migration is a serious threat to the security of European citizens, to peaceful daily life, to our traditional European way of life. The new President of the European Commission is expected to recognise and support the efforts of countries that protect the EU's external borders.  Secondly, Article 4 of the Treaty on European Union states, and I quote – 'the Union respects the equality of the Member States before the Treaties and their national identity, which is an integral part of their fundamental political and constitutional system', the end of the quotation. In recent years, the left-wing pro-immigration majority in the European Parliament has wanted to abolish them by all means, including through the procedure under Article 7 of the Treaty, the rights laid down in Article 4 of the Treaty on European Union. We expect the new President of the European Commission, as head of the body that is the guardian of the Treaties, to do everything possible to fully respect national identity and the constitutional sovereignty of the Member States.  Thirdly, regional development and agricultural support and rural development resources are not donations of mercy to the currently less developed Member States, regions and citizens of the Union, but investments in achieving one of the fundamental objectives of the functioning of the Union, economic, social and territorial cohesion as laid down in Article 3 of the Treaty. We expect the new President of the European Commission to ensure that the eu's next seven-year framework budget does not punish but support the V4 countries, central European Member States, which are developing at a faster pace than the EU average and are making serious efforts to reduce poverty.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, the next five years require leadership that does not consider ‘business as usual’ as the point of departure. We need a European Commission that is ambitious, progressive and not resistant to change.  Ms von der Leyen, it is positive that you plan to make the European Union climate neutral by 2050 and that you are committing to putting this into law during your first 100 days. But when it comes to the 2030 target, keep in mind that this Parliament asked for a 2030 target of 55%, because this is what is in line with the long—term strategy and with the Paris goals.  You speak about extending the Emissions Trading System (ETS). Maritime and aviation need to contribute, but the ETS can never be extended to transport in general, as that risks undermining the CO2 standards we have worked hard for. That’s why we ask for a clear commitment that you will not go back from the CO2 standards that we agreed upon.  We need to see much more on the environment. We need you to speak and commit to a biodiversity strategy and we also need to understand your position on the non-toxic environment strategy.  The EU requires also a revamped industrial policy, an Industry 4.0 that does not focus only on digitisation and automation but includes also the ecological aspect; an industrial policy that takes into account our current workers, our future employees, our students and our youth.  Allow me a final word on migration. You speak about a fresh start on migration. As an MEP hailing from one of the frontline Member States, Malta, I urge you to put migration as a priority, where solidarity does not remain a buzzword but where legislative proposals, such as the Dublin regulation, are enacted and become law so that not only a few countries shoulder the responsibility alone, as is happening today. We need policies that are game—changers if the European project is to move forward, and these are the policies that we, as the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, will be pushing for.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Madam President, along with many colleagues in Renew Europe, I have thought hard about whether to support Ms von der Leyen today. The system that has put her in front of us is clearly broken, but I was placed in this Chamber by millions of British people who believe in the European Union, who demand the best from Europe and who want us to stay here. We would be fools to refuse this opportunity.  Europe needs action, not indecision. But Ms von der Leyen, I tell you firmly and clearly that my vote does not come cheaply. If I am to support you today this is the price that I ask for your support. You must reform this broken system. You must commit real action, and not just words, to the climate emergency. You must immediately begin reform of the Dublin Agreement. And Ms von der Leyen, the price for me will be to use your influence at every table at which you sit to agree a long extension, so that Britain may remain part of this European family.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Minister von der Leyen for her speech. Compared to last week, that’s a huge step, but it really makes me wonder what we are voting for and who we are voting for. There’s so much changing and there’s so much unclear now. For example, on climate change you are fiddling around with the minus 50, minus 55, but what is Europe going officially to put on the table when Paris officially starts in December 2020? It is still unclear. You mentioned in your programme the biodiversity strategy, but there is no word on agricultural policies. What are you going to do about the current reform of agricultural policies?  And then extending ETS to traffic. What does that mean? The carbon prices we need in order to make sure our cars get clean are way higher than those we have now. This sounds like the tune of the German car industry – they would love to see these prices instead of the CO2 standards.  Finally, on the rule of law, there have been some very good words, but one concrete action, so do you support the European Parliament in its Article 7 procedure against Hungary? It’s time you became concrete on that.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, five years ago, in this Chamber, the man you are aiming to succeed, Jean-Claude Juncker, said that it was, I quote, the Commission of last chance. You are therefore in danger of being at the head of the 'Commission of Liquidation', that of the last judgment before the return of peoples and nations to the heart of true European cooperation.  The result of a discussion in Brussels behind the backs of the peoples, methodically kept away from the opaque process of appointing high positions within the European institutions, you are here because you have reassured certain political groups by giving pledges. You will go further and further, and you reaffirmed this morning, in the globalized free trade that is destroying our jobs and exhausting our planet. You will go further and further in the forced federalism that muzzles peoples and locks down nations with, for example, the suppression of unanimity. You will go further and further in migratory laxity and multiculturalism, which endanger the security and identity of our countries.  It is for all these reasons, Madam, that you will certainly have the voices of the Liberals and the left later, and it is also for all these reasons, Madam, that you will not have ours.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Ursula von der Leyen's conviction of the excellence of a United States of Europe is in stark conflict with the member states' right to self-determination. In your vision, Mrs Von der Leyen, the Member States will lose their right to self-determination in your eagerness to complete this vision. A President of the Commission should lead with common sense and, above all, have a sense of reality in order to be able to lead a Europe in which the Member States can cooperate optimally with each other and exchange experiences. A central political union has no support among the electorate, and it is a utopia because the Member States obviously want to retain their identity, their culture and their history. Each Member State is, of course, up for its own interests. What you are supposed to represent is the inhabitants of all Member States and not your personal interests or ambitions. Having heard your speech here today, it is quite clear to me that you are unfit for this task. I will vote against your candidacy, and I hope that the rest of the ECR members will do the same.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Madam von der Leyen, you have arrived here with the unequivocal support of your European party and the governments of the far right. Several hearings and letters later came here to present to the other groups the commitments that their supporters have always rejected and always blocked in this House. I told everyone what everybody wanted to hear. But what the European Union needs at the moment is choices, choices, and so I ask you: in order to have cohesion countries have to compensate for excessive surpluses? You're going to demand that from your government? Or do we invest in combating climate change by serving the planet or invest in militarization serving the German arms industry? Who are you actually going to serve? Either we fight offshore stouts within the European Union or we fight public services. Who are you going to fight? Either you will defend workers' rights or you will continue to recommend their destruction. Who are you going to defend? Either we have a reception policy or we have enhanced border control. Which side are you going to be on? Mrs von der Leyen, we need five years of clear choices, we do not need two more weeks of contradictory promises because Europe can no longer stand a siren-singing mandate and certainly disappointment.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President-designate as a woman and mother of three daughters, I am pleased to see for the first time a woman destined to chair the European executive. This is certainly a good news. But I hope the change doesn't stop there. Because the governments that supported your appointment certainly saw you as a good president, but above all they wanted to say no to those who had pre-packaged a package of appointments with the arrogance to believe that everyone else could only accept them. Those who supported it wanted to reiterate that if we want to live together in Europe, we must also decide together, all together. Mrs von der Leyen, after our meeting, you made the main points of our programme yours, you guaranteed that you would commit yourself to achieving a European minimum wage, a new pact on immigration, ambitious climate reforms and finally guaranteeing legislative initiative in the European Parliament.  That is why the 5 Star Movement intends to support your candidacy, but every day over the next five years, you will have to prove worthy of this trust. We will observe it closely and we will not oppose it even harshly if it does not respect the commitments made, defending the Italian and European citizens, as we have always done. To govern Europe it is not enough to be German, French, Italian or Spanish, you have to take the best of each of us and show the world that the European Union is much more than the sum of its countries. Mrs von der Leyen, both change and the citizens of Europe deserve and do not disappoint us.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, everyone knows that the way in which the Council treated this Parliament and how it designed your Commission has designed you has been inappropriate. But everyone also knows that this is the worst time for an institutional crisis, that Parliament cannot right the anti-Europeans and that the Council's irresponsibility does not exempt Parliament from its own responsibility. The Council was wrong, but Parliament cannot be wrong too. Parliament must be right. That is why we will trust you, because in a world in crisis and on the brink of trade warfare, Europe cannot be led. Because since you have been proposed, you have shown Parliament your respect and committed yourself to European democracy. Because you have shown a capacity for dialogue, and European peace is based on dialogue. Europe is the opposite of dogmatism. Because you believe in a Europe that does not distinguish between East and West, North and South, and that does not want to leave anyone behind. Because you come from the party that has won the election, and your candidacy responds to the will of European voters. Because we share with you your faith in the rule of law and the primacy of constitutions. And, therefore, I am sure that we have you to defend the Spanish rule of law and the unity of Spain. Because its commitment to climate change is undoubted, demanding and exemplary. Because today you represent Europeanism and to vote against you today is to vote in favour of anti-Europeanism. Because it is time for a woman to preside over the European Commission, Mrs von der Leyen. And all those of us who believe in equality between men and women, today, today—precisely today—cannot pass up this opportunity. You count on my vote.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, Ms von der Leyen, there is a reason why you mentioned in quick succession two of the critical issues, which my Group regards as the key priorities, namely the relaunch of the Dublin process and the support for an additional, comprehensive European rule-of-law mechanism. I quote your words in your letter to our Group. And the reason is that, while these issues may not be the only important ones – you mentioned climate change, the social pillar and so on – they are issues which could make or break the European Union. We all know this. And for this reason, you are saying the correct words, giving the headlines that we want to hear, but, as you’ve heard from many Members, we need to have the concrete ideas underneath the words. In the Dublin process, on this so-called Pact for Migration, you and I know that it requires qualified majority voting (QMV) from the Member States. The fact of this inertia in the Council – that there has been nothing on migration, while we see people drowning in the Mediterranean – is something that you can do something about. You mentioned QMV on foreign relations issues, but you didn’t mention it here. And the criminalisation of NGOs, and the humanitarian corridors: all these things are the detail that we need to hear. On the question of support for the rule of law, again, we need the detail: the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the sanctions, Hungary and Poland – name the countries, because this is the essence of what we have to do here in order not to break Europe. Ms von der Leyen, I’m a UK Member, and people are tweeting at the moment that you want an extension, come what may. This is not what you said in a letter to us. You said, in quite a dignified way, that should an extension be required for the United Kingdom there would have to be good reasons. And I think you dealt with the Brexit issue here in a dignified and pragmatic way. Pragmatic – that is the kind of partnership we want to see, as opposed to the kind of fantasy Brexit that we’re hearing about from other people in this Chamber. So, for this reason, pragmatic partnership is the way forward.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, I want to congratulate Ms von der Leyen on an excellent speech and on an excellent process over the last couple of weeks, working with Renew Europe to include our priorities in her programme. I want to say to the Greens and to Mr Eickhout, yes, I think there has been change over the last weeks and I think we have to recognise this change. I don’t think it’s wavering, I think there is a recognition here that there is a challenge which Europe is facing – a challenge that comes from those sides which want Europe to fail, from populists and nationalists who see the frustration and the anxieties that our citizens feel, and who offer this feeling of control and the sense that, well, if we just get back the walls and we divide our countries again then we will recover control and it will be better.  Ms von der Leyen knows that is the wrong alternative, she understands those anxieties and she has shown over these weeks that she can work with us to build a better Europe, to build a Europe that responds to our concerns on democratisation, to all our concerns on the climate, on digitalisation, on the frustration that our citizens feel with how the euro crisis was resolved or not well resolved. For that reason I think this is the moment when all of us here need to make an effort and say, well, maybe not everything is there in this package, but it’s the moment to come together and say ‘no’ to populism and nationalism and ‘yes’ to a better Europe that Ms von der Leyen is offering us today.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, Madam Candidate, you have indicated in the hearings your support for the agreement between the European Union and Mercosur.
