What is the value of the climate commitment you have just made when, in this agreement, you support a Bolsonaro president who decided to massacre the Amazon for agribusiness and mining projects?  What is the value of your commitment to women's rights when Bolsonaro attacks women's rights every day, attacks homosexuals every day, attacks civil liberties every day and defends child labour? This is not the social Europe that you claim to be defending.  Madam candidate, the agreement with Mercosur is the globalization of junk food, it is the climate runaway, it is the disappearance of peasants in the north and south, peasants whose words you did not say a word in your speech.  So if you want to defend the European project, if you do not want to sell Europe to the multinationals of agribusiness and the car lobby, if you do not want to give Europe to the far right, brazil and in this Chamber, if you want to give it back to the citizens, then condemn and stop the agreement with Mercosur and review the european Commission's copy on the common agricultural policy. There, you will be in line with your values.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Madam President, I have only one minute so I have only a few sentences to say. The first thing is that we have a lot of emotions here, and that is absolutely understandable because a lot of us don’t like the other side and other sides don’t like us. That’s fine. It’s part of democracy.  I have met Mr Timmermans a few times and I know that he was one of the problems in the European Council concerning the next candidate for the leader of the Commission. But it was his positions and his ideas about his political views were also problematic. I was listening to Ms von der Leyen on her climate policy, immigration policy and the federalisation of the European Union. I would like to say that there is no big difference between Mr Timmermans and Ms von der Leyen. It’s pragmatic policy, I understand, but it’s a fact.  I have only ten seconds left. I would just like to say that all the Member States in the Schengen area have agreed that we have to protect our external borders, like Italy is doing now, and like Hungary with our EUR 1 billion; we are even helping Germany with that. We have to stop illegal human trafficking because a lot of people here are in favour  of giving millions of euros to traffickers who are getting money thanks to this migration, and we are just saying here, ‘oh that’s absolutely fine’, and ‘we have to open the borders’. I don’t think it’s a very smart way to go forward, but anyway, good luck with the evening and I really hope that we will also have another candidate.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, the first conclusion I draw from this whole thing is that the Spitzen candidate phenomenon has failed, because Mr Weber is sitting there in his chair – you are listening to it now – when he should have been sitting there. It's just a small step for you, but a huge leap for the European Parliament. So you're gone, and with that, the system actually got a state funeral and died on the Boulevard of Broken Dreams.  Secondly, Mrs von der Leyen, your promises. You have been with us and you have made numerous promises. Next, I hear about promises to the Macronists, to the Socialists, to the Greens and so on. I compare them, and they're all different things. Then I'm like, how is that possible? You read your list as a kind of Oberlehrerin, but I still wonder what those words, those promises are actually worth. Third, the Bundeswehr.  The Bundeswehr has known all kinds of abuses and situations, but you blamed the bundeswehr summit. You blamed them for a Haltungsproblem, but I wonder if you do not have a Haltungsproblem yourself, because you are politically responsible for it. If something goes wrong in the European Commission, where I myself have worked for seven years, are you going to blame these people for a Haltungsproblem? My question is therefore: what is your ability to look in the mirror?

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. Today's vote is a climate change vote. We are in the midst of an acute climate crisis. The question on which we are taking a position is whether or not we want the necessary green transition. We have heard the answer from Mrs von der Leyen today and the answer from Mrs von der Leyen is a clear 'no'. The answer from Mrs von der Leyen is no.  50 percent reduction in CO2 emissions by 2030 is not enough to avoid a climate disaster. 55 percent reduction is also not enough to avoid a climate disaster.  We need climate action now. That is why I am going to vote against von der Leyen, and I would urge all those who went to the polls to ensure green conversion to do the same. Now is the time to act. You can act if you vote no today. Now is the time to put action behind the words. Why: Vote for the climate. Vote to avoid a climate disaster. And vote against Mrs von der Leyen in the vote later today.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, Mrs Von der Leyen, before I go to my debate, I would just like to ask you if the European Union governed by such relations will survive the next economic crisis? You represent everything that is wrong in Europe, you represent centralization, you represent the deficit of democracy, you represent the economic hegemony of the center in relation to the periphery.  We're talking about centralization. A few days ago, Italy received its seventh President of the European Parliament. Congratulations to Mr. Sassoli. The 7th President of the European Parliament! Germany and France, correct me, already had six, many countries in the center had a higher number, while fifteen countries of the periphery, including Croatia, had a straight zero. It's a similar thing in the European Council, it's a similar thing in the European Commission.  When will Croatia or another member, Malta, Slovakia, get its fair share, "fair share"? Never!  As for democracy, you come here before us, and you have no legitimacy. What election process did you participate in? What voters did you represent to the voters that you had the legitimacy here to ask the representatives of these voters, two hundred million of them, for legitimacy? The deal in Brussels is unfair, unfair. He's undemocratic, he's arranged behind closed doors, and you're bringing us here before the end of the act. Again the old powerful members in the center have agreed: the French will take the Central Bank, the Germans will take the Commission, Belgium will take the Council, for the periphery again nothing!  You're talking about Syria, how you took a boy from Syria into your home. Well done. But with the other hand, you're talking about NATO, a permanent generator of instability, and an imperialist force that serves no peace. Croatia has no use for such a relationship, only harm.  It can be done either honestly or not at all. You won't have my vote.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, a great French writer, Charles Péguy, wrote: "You have to have the courage to say what you see, but more importantly, you have to have the courage to see what you see." Let us face reality: Europe is in deep crisis, it seems doomed to impotence in the face of economic challenges, in the face of migration challenges, in the face of the great powers that today seem to be writing the history of the world. It is the destiny of our civilization that is at stake today. There is only one way to reduce anxiety and scepticism, it is to re-found a Europe that puts itself at the service of the peoples of Europe and which allows us to no longer suffer, no longer suffer the imbalances of globalisation, this lack of strategy that has caused us to lose our industrial strengths, our know-how, our ability to produce what we consume. I am thinking in particular of farmers and I regret, in fact, that they were not mentioned more this morning. Agriculture is the first policy of the European Union and we will never accept here in the EPP that it serves as an adjustment variable. We no longer want to suffer the imbalances that cause the ecological crisis and it is to face this challenge that Europe, thank you for saying this morning, must finally impose a carbon contribution on all the countries that export to the European Union. We no longer want to suffer the same powerlessness in the face of the migration crisis. Yes, every death in the Mediterranean Sea is a tragedy. But yes, each of these tragedies is the result of a single cause that is our impotence. Too many people take all the risks to come to Europe, because they know that the only condition to settle there is to get there illegally. It is therefore finally necessary to control Europe's external borders and it is the duty of humanity that commands it. To welcome is not to suffer, it is also the condition to regain the balance of our societies and to pass on to the coming generations this magnificent civilization that we have inherited. Mrs von der Leyen, we have a future to save and that future is very much at stake in the next five years. The people of Europe are counting on us to keep their eyes open.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, the turnout in the European elections was the highest ever in the Netherlands. There was a frantic campaign to convince the electorate. TV debates were organised between the European leaders. In the end, there was a vote for optimism, but also for influence on who would become the new President of the Commission. After all, a large majority in the European Parliament was clear: we would only engage with one of the Spitzen candidates as President of the new Commission, just as we had five years earlier.  The elections were over and the tombola began. In the end, your name came out of the top hat of european heads of government. A common sound in the Netherlands is: why did I vote? People feel cheated and I get that feeling very well. In the Council, the Spitzencandidate process led by a semi-autocrat such as Viktor Orbán was turned around. The Polish and Hungarian governments celebrate your nomination as their political victory. You can't be blamed for that personally, but that is why it is particularly important that you take a clear stand on the rule of law in this debate.  Hence my simple question: do you support the Article 7 proceedings initiated by the Commission and Parliament against the Polish and Hungarian Governments in recent years? Because there should be no doubt about that.  The fuss surrounding your speech shows that we still have a long way to go to make Europe more democratic, and that means even more commitment from you, but also from us. Mrs von der Leyen, your speech contains a number of points that will appeal to progressive voters. If you are elected today, you will have the support of the Labour Party in the coming years in a green, fair and social Europe.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Thank you, Madam President. Welcome to the European Parliament, Mrs von der Leyen. Many things have just been said, already: migration, climate, rule of law. So I'm going to be able to shorten it a little bit. Of course, our policies are our foundations, but I would say that what is cardinal for us this morning, for you this morning, is to retricotate the bond and trust, first with us, the European Parliament, and then with the Europeans, quite simply. You are not responsible, Mrs von der Leyen, we must nevertheless remind him from time to time, of the original sin committed by the Council, of these three days of mercato undrinkable in the eyes of all. And I applaud, we applaud your formal commitments to land the reform proposals in this regard, during the work of the future Convention. In telegraphic style, now, because time is running out, I remain short on three essential issues. First of all, the common agricultural policy: you have been remarkably discreet on this issue, to use an understatement. Our technological backwardness, digital technology, artificial intelligence, robotics and industrial policy: what are we doing, what are you proposing to finally bring out European champions? There are aborted mergers that hurt, again. And then, and this has not been said so far, it is a double first as far as you are concerned: you are a woman but you are a doctor, and I am delighted. Mrs von der Leyen, you may not know it, but health was the poor relative of the last Commission and the challenges are innumerable and cross-border: epidemics, rare diseases, Lyme, shortage of medicines - we talk about it in the press every day - vaccines, anti-vaccines... What are you going to do? Are you going to do better? Anyway, you have our support and support.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Ms von der Leyen that I happy that, in her political guidelines, she says that ‘trade is not an end in itself, it should deliver prosperity at home and export our values across the world’. But, we all know that, by importing products, we export breaches of human rights, of victims of modern slavery of indigenous peoples, we cause deforestation by consuming chocolate, textiles and other products. Would you support a mandatory European law on human rights due diligence to European companies so that we can shed light on the unethical aspects of the supply chains?  A second question: I come from the northernmost part of Europe and I would like to remind you that climate crisis has some of the most dramatic consequences in the Arctic Circle and Europe. Your agenda for Europe does not even mention the Arctic. So my question is, will you take Arctic policy as one of your political priorities for the new Commission?

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As a newly elected Member, I was surprised by the procedure for electing the President of the Commission. Frankly, it is regrettable that a significant proportion of the electorate in Europe is deliberately ignored and that it gives the impression that important decisions are being taken behind closed doors. This does not create confidence, but resentment. However, I would like to remain constructive in my remarks.  My concerns relate to internal security and border control, and in particular to the threat posed by international Islamist terrorism. We have seen the security policy challenges posed by the so-called open door policy in Germany and other European countries, and the considerable burdens on the often overstaffed and broken police and our security services. In view of the continuing uncontrolled immigration and the vulnerability to attacks such as that of Anis Amri and others, I fear that, unfortunately, the real security problems we face are not diminishing, but greater. I therefore hope, Mrs von der Leyen, that you can assure us that your comments on internal security have not been empty words.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, my name is Assita Kanko and I am one of the seven children of a woman who had to run and hide when she decided to divorce – chased away by religious and traditional prohibitions. When my last sibling was born she was 37. I turned 39 last Sunday and I have only one kid, by choice. But also because, for millions of female genitally-mutilated women, giving birth is more complicated – I am one of them. And I am grateful for this freedom to stand here and talk to you.  I’m asking you this question as a Fleming and a woman, as a little girl who did not escape FGM and as a concerned mother. In Europe we close our eyes when the Islamic State kidnapped and raped women and girls like Nobel Prize winner, Nadia Murad. We look away when girls are cut on European soil – 500 000 is the number of those who live today with the consequences of FGM inside the EU. We look away when there are honour crimes, Sharia courts, segregation and Islamic radicalisation, which is bad news for women and our European values.  How are you going to use your position to protect all women regardless of their religion and tradition? Article 1 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights has yet to apply to them. You can do this inside a strong Europe, not a superstate for top jobs but one about the people and which adds value and respects subsidiarity.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, what are you going to say to the more than 500 million European citizens who did not elect you? What will be your legitimacy to deal with the climate crisis and the inequality crisis? Will you continue to tell us that the crates are empty, as your predecessors did? Yet there is money for our public services, as well as for the ecological transition. And it's in tax havens. More than 800 billion euros is the cheque, the cheque you write every year, that the European Union makes every year to tax evaders, Google, Amazon, Bernard Arnault. A cheque for which all European citizens pay the price. As Victor Hugo said: it is from the hell of the poor that the paradise of the rich is made. And this paradise has found a new president: you, Madame von der Leyen. Not a commitment, not a word, not an ounce of action against European tax havens, such as Luxembourg or Malta. You are their candidate, Mrs von der Leyen, not ours, not the people of Europe. No rich man fears you, no poor man believes you. You embody the reasons for the anger of the peoples, not the answer to that anger. So, Mrs von der Leyen, take a good look at this check for tax evaders, we'd rather rip it up than vote for you.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the appointment of the President to the Commission is the result of a tough haggling in the context of the competition that is growing in the European Union due to the low performance recorded by the European economy. Regardless of controversy, whoever is elected President, the new Commission will continue the European Union's basic strategy: boosting the profitability of monopolies, restricting popular freedoms, file, anti-communistism, cracking down on workers' rights in all Member States, militarization, imperialist aggression that reinforces dangerous planning and challenging sovereign rights by Turkey's civil order in the Aegean, in the Cypriot Exclusive Economic Zone. Immediately after the emergence of the New Democracy in the government of our country, the Eurogroup discussed the course of the Greek economy within the framework of the syriza agreements with the government against the background of the fourth evaluation and the medium-term programme 2020-2023. The Commission and the Eurogroup identify a number of budgetary gaps, requiring strict compliance with 3.5% of primary surpluses, commitments under post-monumental enhanced surveillance, i.e. new heavy measures on the backs of the Greek people, at a cost of EUR 4.5 to 6 billion. These decisions form the basis for the new democracy government's policy, provide for a general auction of popular housing, an increase in tax collection measures for non-performing loans, new cuts in pensions, allowances, privatisations, greater commercialisation of health, welfare and education. Workers in Greece and Europe must draw important conclusions, organize themselves to assert their modern rights to work, to life, to the education of their children.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you have designed a policy for the future of Europe that we can largely support. If we want to combat unemployment, we must have an economic policy which, however, focuses above all on the real economy. We need a European industrial policy that has a target, as there is for environmental policy, 20% of gross domestic product must come from manufacturing, industry and agriculture.  I would ask you, when you are President of the Commission, to strengthen the GROW Directorate-General, I would ask you to implement the Small Business Act to support small and medium-sized enterprises, and I would ask you to defend our industries against the Chinese assault. It has made some interesting proposals, but we must also have very serious anti-dumping rules. We must defend ourselves against the web giants that have to pay taxes like all other businesses, but we also need to strengthen agricultural policy. Cuts in the CAP are a mistake, and we must not forget that industry and agriculture are two fundamental instruments for creating jobs in our European Union. Then, of course, as you said, access to credit: we need to move forward with the Banking Union, we need to develop a capital market.  As far as immigration is concerned, I would ask you to reflect on what the European Parliament has also voted for, plus money for a real plan for Africa, we need EUR 50-60 billion. In 2050 we will have two and a half billion Africans, if we do not act today, the Frontex guards are not enough, we need a real strategy to invest in Africa, combat climate change, poverty, diseases, defend agriculture and fight terrorism. If Europe does not act, we will have an invasion of millions of people, not thousands. So the next European Commission needs to do a lot.  I will end with the rule of law, you said very fair words, but today it is exactly 21 months since the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, a journalist murdered in Malta. We still don't know who was in charge of that murder. We must defend the rule of law everywhere. We must defend freedom of expression and also in countries outside the European Union, I am thinking of Venezuela, where there are millions of citizens of European, Italian, Spanish and Portuguese origin, including Germans who continue to suffer as a result of a dictatorship. I believe that, from this point of view too, the European Commission, as Parliament has done, must make its voice heard loud and clear, because we are above all a community of values. You have said that, and I believe that we must continue to move in this direction over the next five years.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs von der Leyen, I cannot help but acknowledge that in your letter to our group you have included many of our demands. You have made many points that we, as Social Democrats, fought for during the election campaign, your own, including those such as unemployment reinsurance, against which your party fought passionately. I would be pleased to see that there would not be a nagging suspicion that the Member States would make your commitment so small in the course of the negotiations until it became unrecognisable, and that with the Christian Democrat governments first and again. I must therefore note your announcements with some scepticism. Now I could certainly give you an advance of confidence, but for me there are institutional and very fundamental arguments against it. During the election campaign, I campaigned for the leading Social Democrat candidate – a Dutchman named Frans Timmermans – and here too I decided on political common goals and values, not nationality. And I have promised my constituents – as all social democratic candidates from the SPD have done – that we will only elect one leading candidate. And I'm going to keep that promise, and we're 16. Many, not only in this House, have praised the leading candidate process as a win for European democracy. My concern is that today we are seeing the singing of the leading European candidate. That is why I would like to ask you: how would you like to receive guarantees from the European Council that this is not the case? (Applause)

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, it is a great honour and a great responsibility for me to stand here in the heart of European democracy and deliver not only my first comments, but the first comments made by my party in any parliament. I am a new MEP from Hungary, a wonderful country that many of you only hear about when there is a new attack on the rule of law or on civil society. I know that many of you are fed up with this. As a Hungarian, I’m also fed up, because until now the European elite has turned a blind eye and appeased populists like Viktor Orbán. This has to change now.  We must fight back against those who seek to destroy our Union and ensure it remains a community of values. We must keep Europe united, prosperous and secure. For that we need a leadership that is not afraid to defend European democracy. We expect actions, not words. The next Commission must provide specific safeguards for protecting the rule of law, and leaders with the political will and ability to implement them. Because today, standing for Europe is often seen as standing for the status quo – but the status quo is not good enough: we need real change. (Applause)

name: Monika VANA
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Minister von der Leyen, you have spoken a great deal today about peace in Europe. I myself come from a military-neutral country, Austria, and as a Green and a campaigner for a peace union, I am very critical of the Pesco Military Union and the European Defence Fund, and also of the debate on an EU army or army for Europeans, as you like to call it. A majority of EU citizens do not see defence as an EU priority either, but rather climate protection, social issues, health or education, and a majority of EU citizens are also betting that the EU should focus more on diplomatic and humanitarian measures than on military action to deal with crises and conflicts in the world.  We therefore believe that it is the wrong way to increase the EU's defence spending substantially with the Armaments Fund, where we lack the money for social and climate measures. We do not need billions in arms, Minister, we need climate and social billions.  I would therefore like to ask you whether, as President of the Commission, you will make a credible commitment to a disarmament initiative, to limit defence spending in favour of social and climate protection measures and to binding arms export control.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Minister, thank you also for your speech. I believe that she should also have opened the eyes of the last Member that you are certainly the wrong person for this office. We have also seen that the PPE-DE has now mutated from a supposedly conservative group to a left-green group. What we heard was a document of the most laughable opportunism. You - a miracle bag. Everything was in it: minimum wage, gender equality, climate bank, sustainable Europe, of course empowerment of children, MeToo, strengthening middle class, fair taxes. Their understanding of politics seems to be to adapt the politics to contemporary left-green triviality. And above all: Behind all this there is only one thing – yourself, your function, your position – that is the impression of your presentation. You are not concerned with anything in terms of content.  For us, Europe is about homeland, about identity, about everything that makes us. They seem to be concerned only with a new post, a new political trophy, yes, a new company car licence. Honestly, what do you really want here? So, with this speech that you have given, you can only warn everyone: you should not elect this woman as the new President of the European Commission.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, we are really concerned to see that, in the end, there is virtually no difference between a Timmermans candidate and a von der Leyen candidate. We have seen how you spoke today, always seeking the satisfaction of the left side, the liberals, the Socialists, to whom you have written explaining the project you have. But he hasn't explained it the other way. And that is where the really serious thing is happening right now: that you have already practiced this health belt towards part of the Europeans. We are seeing how a roller is being imposed that punishes peoples who choose governments that some do not like. And that's very, very dangerous. And we also see how those parties elected by peoples are punished here, with a policy and with an opinion that some do not like, who do not like that majority that has been created here, in that consensus where Timmermans and you are the same, are practically the same, and they are only trying to marginalize one party. And you say that you will always be in front of those who are against unity. But I believe that there is really no worse attack on the unity of the European Union and Parliament than these health cords that dynamit the whole democratic spirit, dynamit the rules and finally dynamit all illusions about making a common project.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, many of us thought that Brexit is a lesson and an opportunity for the European political elite, a signal that a change of course is necessary. EU citizens are rightly discontent with the undemocratic and intransparent decision-making in this House and in other EU institutions.  Ms von der Leyen, your reference to a strengthening of the Spitzenkandidaten system was somewhat ironic, if not cynical; this is the system that was ditched in order to nominate you here. The Spitzenkandaten system is far from being perfect, but it was a step in the right direction to select a nominee to head the European Commission. Your nomination just shows that the leaders of the EU ignored the voice of the European electorate and don’t learn from their earlier mistakes. Such decisions and ignorance fuel euroscepticism and criticism, so beware and don’t be surprised: this is a disappointment for those who wish to see a stronger, more credible, more democratic and more transparent EU. Ms von der Leyen, it is not your fault, but you have greatly contributed to this disappointment, and this is why many people in this Chamber find your nomination unacceptable.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to greet Mrs von der Leyen for her inspired and inspiring speech, her vision, conviction and European ambition. You will certainly have our support, but I would also like to make two observations: the first is that I am sorry that, being a doctor, and having a particular sensitivity to health, you have not yet referred to the Master Plan that the EPP proposed in its campaign to fight cancer. It is a very great ambition that we have in our group and which we hope the next Commission can fill in. That said, I was going to ask a question, and that's the central question for me, given that it hasn't been touched by anyone yet and had a simple sentence in her speech about the MFF, the financial outlook for 2021-2027. In fact, what we see in cohesion policies is that the proposal that the Commission has put forward is unfair. Just to give an example: a country like Italy, which is on the European average, rises 6 % in cohesion, a country like Croatia drops 6 %, a country like Finland, which is well above the European average, rises 5 %, a country like Lithuania drops by 23 %. I am talking about neighbouring countries that we can compare to see how unfair the cohesion strategy is coming out of the Commission's proposal and why? Because the Commission cut 45% of the Cohesion Fund without explanation and the Cohesion Fund balanced the ERDF and the European Social Fund.  This harms the poorest countries. There are many priorities in the European Union, but, Ms. von der Leyen, the issue of cohesion and convergence between Member States is central. He appealed here to unity. If the MFF is not to be reviewed towards the solution and position which the European Parliament has adopted, I can say that there will be cohesion problems, that there will be problems of unity between the various Member States.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, you have delivered a skilful performance, you have ticked many boxes, but not all, since the uncertainty remains on many subjects, notably the PSC or agriculture, and you have avoided all the encryption. You are also before us because you have gone through a particularly questionable appointment process, following a series of small arrangements between the representatives of the Member States, who, moreover, have little presence to support you today in their chairs. The Council ignored at all the voice of the citizens, who had adhered to the principle of the Spitzenkandidaten as representatives of their political will. The Council's hat-trick also marginalises the role of the European Parliament, making it a European junior partner. One example illustrates the vagueness of your intervention: on migration and asylum issues, it is not at all enough to hear you say that you want to reform for the Xith time the asylum package that has been reformed and over-reformed, to the point of making it illegible and even blocking it. Personally, I would have liked to hear you talk about a major rescue operation at sea, which would also have allowed us to defend the dignity of the European Union in the face of the divisions of the Council. In the end, this is what is missing from your speech: the testimony that you will be in combat and that you will change the direction of Europe.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: – Mr President, I must say a few sincere words to Madam von der Leyen. I was rather critical of your nomination. I was rather critical of you becoming the President of the Commission. But then, the process we had, actually made me feel respected as a Member of the European Parliament, as a representative of my Swedish voters. For that I condone you.  But also for the respect that you showed our group, the Renew Europe Group, the group that grew most in the European Parliament and that defeated the populists throughout Europe – thank you for that respect, which is also why you will have my vote today. Because you showed a sincere interest in what Parliament does think. Also, I remember what the procedure was like five years ago, when I don’t think many colleagues felt that they had a proper intervention with Commission President Juncker. We had proper interventions with you and you did listen. For that I respect you.  But we will also hold you responsible on your mechanism on initiatives. For example, an animal welfare framework law has been asked for by this Parliament by a majority of about 80% of the Members for five years. Nothing has happened so far. We will come back to it as soon as you have your college in place. We will recall that request and we will hold you accountable to it.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, those wanting to stop the UK’s disastrous crash out of the EU should feel greatly encouraged by Dr von der Leyen’s comments about Brexit. Dr von der Leyen, I was delighted to hear you call yourself a Remainer to our group, and to say that you would be willing to give us the extra time we may need to resolve this deeply damaging episode in our country’s history. But on a range of issues, from tax and trade to climate and protecting life in our countryside, there is a gulf between your views and the green agenda for change. Most importantly, I cannot vote for you because the appointments process that led us here is a step away from closer engagement with citizens and from democracy. The backroom deal done in the Council explicitly reassured the far right in the countries of central Europe, where the rule of law is under threat and democratic standards are at risk. It’s so disappointing that the election of the Commission President will depend on the votes of the far right, rather than those of a strong pro-European majority that could have been achieved by offering the radical change that Green voters demand.  (Applause)

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam Federal Minister, I will be brief: you are a mis-appointed in every respect, regardless of the office. As Minister for Family Affairs, you had to have your initiatives, which were completely unusable, marketed by an advertising agency financed with taxpayers' money, in order to be able to impose them on the German people. As Minister of Defence, you leave behind demoralized soldiers, a Bundeswehr neutered in terms of defence capability, but in which you instead provided extensive childcare facilities and thus transformed the Bundeswehr into a ridiculous day care center. The decency, of course, requires you to wish you luck for your choice. I do so in the confidence that you will be able to continue your destructive work in the European Commission. You want to do without my support. Please take note of the following: I, as a long-standing, convinced – now former – CDU voter tell you: Rather, let me sit down my hand than that I will ever re-elect you or your party in my life.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Dr von der Leyen that I am greatly disturbed by her attachment to the political project of a European army and European strategic autonomy. This will inevitably lead to a transatlantic divide and undermine NATO, and can only encourage our enemies. But let me focus on our most critical issue, as far as the UK is concerned. Dr von der Leyen, we welcome your statement of respect for the decision of the British people to leave the European Union and of the need to work closely with Britain in the future. Goodwill on the part of Brussels has so far been rather missing. But we are disappointed that all you seem to offer is an extension of our withdrawal date: this is hardly ambitious. Instead, may we suggest you use your influence before you take office to urge amendment or reinterpretation of those aspects of the Withdrawal Agreement that are clearly unacceptable to the UK. This wouldn’t take a lot; solutions are there. In Europe, as they say, nothing is possible and everything is possible. Britain will leave the European Union on 31 October. Let’s ensure this is on good terms, without acrimony, to provide the basis for a strong positive relationship in the future, fully respectful of the expressed desire of the British people for control of their own borders and their own laws.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear President, the foundation of development and progress, but also of the survival of the European Union is equality and the rule of law. Equality and the rule of law are primarily manifested in the way representatives are elected. Of the 130 representatives in the European Parliament, twenty presidential and vice-presidential posts went to Germany. Croatia and Slovenia are zero, so zero percent.  Furthermore, the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament require that these places be distributed on the basis of geographical affiliation. So the rule of law was also violated. Something like that is inadmissible.  So we have a Germany that has twenty representatives, which is contrary to equality and represents equality. And now, we should still elect the President of the European Commission from Germany. This is absolutely unacceptable because it is not a Europe of equality and such a Europe is questioning the European Union.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, after the elections in the Netherlands, it was quickly clear that the constructive centre will have to take responsibility if we are to ensure that this Europe continues to function. Because the flanks – Madam candidate, you have heard it enough – think your plans are either too much or too little. Perhaps that's the best sign that you've found a good balance.  There has been a great deal of talk in this House about your nomination and the way in which it has been achieved. But, ladies and gentlemen, that Parliament may also look very critically at itself. The candidate has spoken of the importance of unity, and it is precisely this unity that this Parliament has not shown after the elections. Thinking that you can burn the Spitzen candidate of the largest political party to the bone, because then you hope to get the second Spitzen candidate, that was incredibly naive. Those people who have nothing to do with transparency, with democracy, with a strong European Parliament, of course jump on that horse and leave, Macron and Orbán – what a special combination – leading the way. I therefore welcome the commitments made by this candidate to ensure that the damage done by the Council must be limited towards 2024.  But I am also happy that this candidate started her speech by mentioning Simone Veil, who was not only President of this House but who was also one of the first female members – one of the few, unfortunately female members – of the Académie Française, and when she became a member of the Académie Française she received a sword. On this sword she made sure that there were three engravings – 78561, her number in Auschwitz, reminding us every day why we have this Europe and why we should fight for it every day; the motto of the French Republic; and the motto of Europe, 'unity in diversity' – and the choice we have ahead of us tonight – those who are responsible, those who are constructive – is: are we going to be guided in our vote by frustration and about anger the Council's backroom deal or, in the spirit of Simone Veil, will we build, together with this candidate, the Europe that our citizens need?

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take a step back from the European elections last May, when the nationalist parties that showed up betting on the failure and collapse of Europe have not achieved their goal for the time being.  The citizens of Europe still want to believe in Europe. That is why, Mrs von der Leyen, we ask you to live up to this objective, to give a strong signal of relaunching the European dream, of innovation, as well as of having a woman for the first time to preside over such an important institution. Let me say this to him in two words: we want a europe that is solid and supportive, that no longer turns the other way in front of those who are left behind, but that has the courage to use all the flexibility provided for in the Stability Pact for growth and employment, that finally points to a new model of development, which unambiguously puts the environmental issue not as a limit – as we have too often seen here too – but as an opportunity that does not hold back the But it is fuelling growth because it makes it sustainable, and in this way you would be using the pretext of those who have said, here too, even today, that you are elusive on this point. We want a Europe that does not wink at the nationalists by a handful of more votes in this House, but keeps the bar of Europeanism firmly on the back, made up not of walls but of shared responsibility, as when it comes to economic governance but also immigration. We did it in here when we changed the Dublin system. If that is the vision, but only if that is the vision and action of the next Commission, we will be there.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would say to the President—designate that 15 years ago Central Europeans gave their trust to the European project and now that trust is eroding. Many proposals in the past created an east—west divide on many issues – from Single Market issues to the dual quality of products, posting of workers and issues such as how to make Europe more secure.  It is extremely important that the new Commission adopt a new and different approach. The EU must work to rebuild trust, the trust the people have lost; to ensure that we listen to each other before any proposal is made; to continue to abolish the existing barriers in the internal market, and not to create new ones; to treat all EU citizens equally, with equal access to work and study anywhere in Europe.  Madam President—designate, I hope you can pledge today to be the voice of all EU citizens.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, very good morning. Your candidacy represents a triple resignation, I have to tell you. The renunciation of the parliamentaryization of community political life. The resignation of a strong defence of the rule of law, because we cannot forget that you are here because Mr Timmermans was veted by some countries for being courageous in this matter. And a renunciation of a political agenda of change, since the one you have presented to us has many limitations, as my colleagues have already said. In addition, your Commission can begin with an original sin that will drag throughout the mandate, if you are elected with some votes from the far right today — by the way, colleagues, something that will put in check the credibility of the exercise of the health cord that we are trying to do in this chamber. That is why, Madam Minister, I will not be able to vote on your candidacy. I think Parliament would do well to reject it. And to those who are telling us that for Europeanism we have to support their candidacy, I would like to tell you that always and constantly subjecting the European Parliament to the Council's manoeuvres and bad decisions is the worst favour we can do Europe. Therefore, out of democratic, institutional and European dignity, its candidacy , I believe - must be rejected and we must ask the Council to hold a new summit.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam President-designate, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Waiting for the What we are witnessing here is a lesson in how not to do it. We have all had to listen a great deal because of our scepticism about the promises of democracy and top candidates here in Brussels, but you will far exceed that scepticism with the election of Mrs von der Leyen. It was a strange spectacle that you, Mr Weber, to which you led the campaign for top candidates, were the first to congratulate us today and call for the election of Mrs von der Leyen, and the question I ask myself is: do you actually have self-respect? Anyone who has dealt with Mrs von der Leyen a little can know that, as Minister of Defence in Germany, she has completely failed. It has turned the German army into an army in which the planes do not fly, the tanks do not drive and the rifles do not shoot. And even if we are going to vote against them out of responsibility, I can only say one thing to all those who think they have to vote for them: you cannot put a larger fission mushroom and a larger explosive device in the Commission than someone who has failed in all the ministerial posts in Germany.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: " Dear President, Mrs. Von der Leyen, you have put forward a very ambitious plan, but we have heard little about how you plan to implement it. For a moment, you took me back to my childhood. Growing up in socialist Yugoslavia, I had the opportunity to hear some grandiose ideas similar to yours. Brotherhood and unity, political integration, a common army, greater labour and women's rights, and we know how that ended. Your vision will end the same because the townspeople don't want it. If they wanted to, you wouldn't be dreading whether you'd have a majority in this home today. You are talking about unity and equality in Europe, and you forget that all the top functions of the EU institutions have been possessed by the old members and you are still proposing to vote in the field of foreign and security policy. So much for equality. In your speech, you mentioned the foundations of Europe in Greek philosophy and Roman law, but as a Christian you failed to mention Christianity. Your Europe is fleeing its roots, and that is why it is now so disjonited.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs von der Leyen, we would like to point out that we will vote confidence in you, but that our confidence will never be in the dark, it will never be taken for granted for a minute. On the contrary, our support will be a weapon for us, to act as a sting to your political action.  We have heard you talk about a fair and equitable Europe, about protecting the environment and about women and workers. We have heard you talk about the hourly minimum wage and the obligation to save lives. Well, the European Union must assume its responsibilities on this and other issues and, for example, it can no longer pass on the epochal phenomenon of immigration to a single state. The European Union must once again become what was in the founders' plans, the driving force for peace, development and growth for all European countries. It wasn't like that for everyone. In Italy, youth unemployment is high and it is difficult for a young person to start a family. So, Candidate von der Leyen, we want the European Union at last to provide everyone, farmers, fishermen, entrepreneurs, workers, young people and European citizens with all the same opportunities for development, and that is why we will also be calling for a serious and concrete commitment to put an end to the scandal of tax havens, to the harmonisation of tax policies at work and to very strict common anti-Mafia legislation.  If the many good intentions of your speech become reality, you will be able to count on our loyal support, but if these turn out to be only words, if Europe remains the one that has penalised certain areas such as southern Italy, you will find in the delegation of the 5 Star Movement the most decisive and fierce opposition i can imagine.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Mrs von der Leyen, I hope that everyone who believes in European cooperation today will support you. It looks like the extreme left and the extreme right will vote against you today. I think you should see that as an honor. I am surprised that the Green Group seems to be choosing this company today. I must also say that I think that we are a little ashamed to vote against the first woman to be able to become President of the Commission and, moreover, a person who can succeed in garnering a majority in favour of a progressive climate policy in Europe. Because we have a lot to work together on in Europe now. This is not only about the climate, but it is also important to combat cross-border crime. Freedom of movement in Europe is self-evident to us, but it should not apply to criminals and terrorists. In this area, we also need to strengthen police cooperation. Immigration policy is also absolutely crucial – that we can achieve greater cooperation and a sufficient majority to achieve an immigration policy that is not only more legally secure but also much more controlled. I am absolutely convinced that it is possible in this European Parliament to gather a majority in favour of an immigration policy that can be led by both heart and brain. Finally, For me, Europe is about freedom, it is about entrepreneurship, it is about increasing security for all our citizens. You have our support today. You also have very high expectations of you, but also expect a European Parliament that will be ready to work together to tackle the key problems in Europe, because we must do so.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Ms von der Leyen for today’s remarks and for the letter she addressed to the S&D Group. It was well received and it added a lot to the discussion we had last week in Brussels. I would also like to recognise her commitment to democracy, rule of law, human rights, a fair and equal Europe, a Europe without dividing lines. Now, I am looking forward to concrete actions and to concrete answers to the questions that were raised by my colleagues.  Also, I would like to draw her attention to another dividing line that she did not address today.   – See on lõhe ida ja lääne vahel, mille ilmekaks näiteks on Euroopa Liidu Nõukogu viimane otsus, kus kõik kõrged Euroopa Liidu ametikohad läksid Lääne-Euroopasse. Ma ei taha Euroopat, mis jaguneb idaks ja lääneks, uuteks ja vanadeks, nendeks, kellel on rohkem häält, nendeks, kellel on vähem häält. Teistmoodi ühtset Euroopat ei ehita. Sellepärast küsin Teilt: kuidas hindate seda otsust ja mida teete selleks, et need lõhed ei süveneks?

name: Cristian GHINEA
text: – Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I want to insist on two important things for the delegation of Romanian in the Renew group. Firstly, economic and fiscal integration must cover not only the Member States of the euro area, but also all European states that want to joining the euro area, such as Romania. We need support in this regard. Secondly, I welcome your intention to start a pan-European mechanism for monitoring the rule of law. It was a condition of the Renew group. Thank you for accepting it. In this respect, I remind you that this European Parliament adopted the principles of such a mechanism two years ago, and we propose that we start the necessary legislation on the basis of this european Parliament resolution.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, we’ve reached the point in the debate where everything has been said but it has not yet been said by everybody. But I would like to congratulate Ms von der Leyen on what I thought was an impressive speech this morning. Ms von der Leyen, you’ve come a long way in your presentation with the House and your interaction with the Groups here. I was particularly struck by your commitment to a gender-balanced College of Commissioners. That will shake things up in itself. The Scottish Government has been gender-balanced for five years now. I commend our experience to you. Congratulations.  And on Brexit: you are aware that Scotland has a particular perspective on this matter, but you should also be aware that there are colleagues from across the House – in England and Wales and Northern Ireland and elsewhere – working hard to bring some sense to Brexit. We are united in the fact that the best Brexit is no Brexit. There are Members of this House who will make noise. Some of us are here to find solutions and I am very glad that you will be an ally in keeping the door open for us. You’re also very welcome to this House but to add another thing to your in-tray, this House is not complete. We are missing three Members from Catalonia, not least our Group colleague Oriol Junqueras. The only solution to this intractable problem will be dialogue, and you, personally, are in a position to be an honest broker in that discussion. I hope you will play that role.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister, when you became Minister for Family Affairs 14 years ago, my wife and I were very pleased, because we knew you. We knew you had seven children, you came from a large family home, and we were expecting our tenth child at the time. We expected you to make a good policy for the families. Unfortunately, we were very disappointed. And when I see today what you have said as a speech! They want to build a Europe built on the foundations of Greek philosophy and Roman law. There is something missing: I miss the Christian foundation, the Christian roots of Europe. Without that, it can't work, it's going to collapse. In this construction, I fear that it will be a new tower building in Babel, or that it will be a house that is now collapsing because it is built on sand. That is what I really wish you could avoid.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Mr President, I would say to Minister von der Leyen that the European Union has launched a humiliating procedure under Article 7 towards Poland. Someone has decided that it is lawful when, for instance, judges accept the robbery of properties from people who are 115 years old while, on the other hand, it is unlawful when we restore people’s influence on the justice system. We are told, for example, that we are implementing a random assignment of matters in court. Every time I ask to be shown at least one example – one, not eight, not ten – of a solution that we implement in Poland which does not exist in another EU country, there is always the same answer. Silence. Madam Minister, that’s why I’m asking: are you going to end this ridiculous political action under Article 7?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Dear President, Mrs Von der Leyen, thank you for your opening statement. However, I would like to remind once again that there was a process of spitzenkandidat here, that we had our spitzenkandidat Mr. Weber. Unfortunately, because of some who pretended to be great Democrats, this process failed and we have you as a candidate today.  I am glad that, however, when the spitzenkandidat process has already failed, the process of respecting the relative majority in this Parliament has succeeded. The European People's Party is the relative winner of this election and I am glad that you, as a representative of our party, are here today.  The other reason I'm glad is that you're a woman. I am especially pleased with your attitude towards gender equality, which you have emphasized. You have highlighted what your Commission will look like and how you will treat half the population of the world and the European Union.  What I have not heard much in your speech, and I believe that you will elaborate later, since I come from the youngest member of the European Union, Croatia, and I know that you have good relations with our Government, with our Defence Minister, however, I have not heard much about the differences between east and west, between north and south, the eurozone, non-eurozone, Schengen, non-Schengen. I think it is very important that enlargement to the Schengen zone happens after all and Croatia is one of the great candidates and I hope you will work on that. I would also like to hear a few words about your attitude towards enlargement to southeast Europe or the so-called Western Balkans.  What I was glad to hear in your speech was your attitude towards the economy. You said that people will not serve the economy, but the economy or the economy will serve people and we cannot spend more than we have earned, we should earn sooner and then share. I'm glad you treat it that way.  Also, your green green deal is to be welcomed, regardless of whether the Greens will vote for you, your green deal is important for the future, for the reasons of our children, for the sustainability. I'm glad you're taking care of that and it will be part of your portfolio.  When it comes to migration, I would be glad if you continued that plan for Africa, too, I remember That Mr. Weber even had a Commissioner for Africa in his program and I would be glad if you continue to work on that. The African continent needs to be addressed, and Europe, in a way, still protected.  In this sense, I would like to congratulate you and I will certainly support you and once again I would like to remind this entire Parliament that we really all remember why we once joined this alliance, which is peace, prosperity and democracy.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, welcome to the home of European citizens. You have not been Spitzenkandidat or socialist, for the time being — then, at the end of the legislature, we will see. He therefore knows that his access to the presidency of the Commission goes down the socialist path. And you seem ready to walk with us, with the commitments you sent to our group yesterday and which you re-assumed this morning, here in plenary. His mandate will have a socialist imronta, with greater social justice, with a European minimum wage, with European unemployment insurance, with a European Children's and Youth Guarantee. We also appreciate their strategy for gender equality, with the elimination of the pay gap, the protection of women from sexist violence and their eagerness to achieve parity in their future Executive. Mrs von der Leyen, if elected, we will work together to finalify your commitments, with directives, with regulations, with appropriate financial instruments and resources. Mrs von der Leyen, if you are elected, we will gladly work with the first woman president of the Commission. Ich w'nsche Ihnen viel Gl'ck.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, Ursula von der Leyen, in your programme you have prioritised climate issues very far, and you have also been asked to take concrete measures, means and solutions in this debate as well. That is why I too would like to raise the issue of climate issues and, of course, forests, which are, of course, seamlessly linked.  It is very important that you work towards a carbon-free Europe and that you are going to take the energy and climate strategy to the finish line.  In the Commission's 2050 vision, the bioeconomy and wood products play a big role when it comes to abandoning the fossil economy.  It is very important that the carbon sequestration of forests is taken care of and is best achieved through active forest management and forestry, rather than by limiting the use of wood. I would therefore like to hear how you would see to it that, in a Europe of growing forest resources, the use of wood is seen as a solution and not as a problem in the fight against climate change. What views do you have on this important practical matter?

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Mr President, I say to Ms von der Leyen: at the last public consultation, the majority of stakeholders and citizens rejected the re-opening of the liability regime of the Directive on Electronic Commerce. As you are well aware, imposing liability on online content service providers and mandatory filtering of content were among the controversial issues during the last copyright reform. Over 250 000 people in Germany alone protested against the devastating Article 13 – now number 17 – of the Copyright Directive and against the introduction of upload filters. More than 5 million signed a petition – the biggest in European history. In contrast with all that, in your agenda for Europe, you seem to support the reopening of the E-commerce Directive and ‘upgrading the liability and safety rules’.  Ms von der Leyen, could you please elaborate on what that upgrade means and confirm that the principle of safe harbour for hosting service providers stays intact and that no mandatory filters will be proposed?

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Mr President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The eurozone, together with Japan, has the lowest growth and the highest taxes in the developed world. An EU co2 tax requires unanimity. You are now questioning the principle of unanimity in tax matters at EU level, Minister. Her department has wasted billions on outside consultants, especially the consulting firm McKinsey. Nevertheless, only about one third of the Bundeswehr's equipment is ready for use. One journalist wrote: "McKinsey uses the Ministry of Defence like an ATM, and the maxim is 'the army fails, the adviser collects, and the taxpayer pays'." Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Do we really want an EU-wide consultant tax on how best to implement German climate and asylum policy anywhere in the EU? Our citizens, however, certainly do not want that.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Minister that just listening to her last week in our Group there was a sign of promise and hope for me but, Minister, reading your letters yesterday and your speech today I have to admit that I am more and more disappointed. You gave in totally to the progressive and green agenda and it’s particularly clear in the climate change policy where you gave in to 95% of the Green Party demands and they want the remaining 5% and maybe you will even be inclined to do it. I guess that instead of adapting ourselves to the climate change, you agreed with these unrealistic goals for 2030 and a vision of a non–carbon society. For me, coming from Czechoslovakia, this reminds me of the promise of a non–class society that goes against nature. And 30 years ago I remember that in China everybody was riding a bicycle while every family in Europe had a car. Do you believe that in 2030 the vision of Europe is that a couple of billionaires will be driving battery–charged Maybach cars and the rest will ride their bicycles and in China everybody will have a car? Is this your vision of Europe being competitive with China in the future?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, a Ursula, ar dtús báire, fáilte Uí Cheallaigh romhat go Parlaimint na hEorpa agus tá súil agam go n-éireoidh go geal leat. For a woman who was plucked from relative obscurity a little over two weeks ago, your performance since, and especially here today, has been truly remarkable. You’ve shown that you’re a woman of great talent, confidence, perspective and calmness, and are well equipped to do the job of Commission President, which I hope you will get this evening by at least 400 plus votes. You mentioned many areas of great importance. The one that mattered most in the European elections was climate change and I welcome your practical approach to that. The one thing I would ask you is to ensure that, as we move to a low—carbon economy, nobody is left behind. We have to have a just transition for all – the turf cutter from Ireland, the steelworker from Germany, the dairy farmer from Italy and the coal miner from Poland.  Spitzenkandidaten have also been mentioned. You are, in some respects, the victim or the beneficiary of it, whichever way you look at it. Would you agree with me that you might set up a working group of nominees from the Council, the Parliament and the Commission to come forward with proposals as to how this can work in the future? In that way, you could rescue the process. I was also very pleased with what you said about Brexit and your consistency in the answers you gave to me at the EPP Group reiterated here today in relation to the backstop, the Withdrawal Agreement and flexibility in regard to an extension if necessary. I would ask you to further underline your support for Ireland in the future, as we had unwavering support from Jean-Claude Juncker, Michel Barnier, etc. Finally, I just want to say to you that gender equality is something that you are in the ideal position to lead and we look forward to that.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mrs von der Leyen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. On behalf of the Polish Social Democrats, I would like to say that our sympathy for you grows with every meeting and every conversation. Here we want to say a firm 'yes' to what you said, without compromising on the rule of law and without exceptions. Secondly, climate protection. Yes, we want to breathe healthy air. Yes, we want to eat healthy food and we are pleased that you have said that the costs of climate protection should be spread fairly. We accept your position, the declaration on strengthening cohesion policy, including the Just Transition Fund – we are in favour. A minimum wage that ensures a decent life in each Member State, according to the situation – yes, we are in favour. In foreign and defence policy, we lacked the Eastern dimension: Russia, Ukraine, the Eastern Partnership – here we have a deficit.  Finally, there is a great geographical imbalance in the distribution of power in the European institutions: Germany, Italy, France – this is the first, highest level; Netherlands, Spain – second layer; new countries – zero. I think that you, as President of the Commission, must do something about it. We are counting on some compensation.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, Mrs Von der Leyen, there is definitely a need for change for the European Union. This was also the message of European citizens at the last elections. It is more than clear that they like the European Union, but do not approve of it as such. They want to see him reformed, effective and working for them. Deepening internal integration is essential, but it must not come at the expense of enlargement of the Union. The integration of the Balkan countries is a key issue for the future of the European Union. Recently, it has been seen that they, for the Balkans, are spoken as a security area, but not as part of the European Union.  The absence of a future Enlargement Commissioner will be an unambiguous sign that the region has been abandoned. Secondly, today we have not just a Union of different speeds, but a Union of different standards - in food, in technology, in international transport. Some are in Schengen and another is subject to an ineffective cooperation and verification mechanism. My question is, what are you specifically going to do in that direction? We have heard a lot of promises from our outgoing Commission, but without concrete results, unfortunately. And coming to an end, it is very important to conclude negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework by the end of this year in order to start implementation in early 2021.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Mr President, I say to Ms von der Leyen: coming from little  Lithuania I am very happy to support your candidacy, first of all because thanks personally to you and to the decisions of the German Government and NATO, we have troops stationed in Lithuania as part of NATO forces. Because of that, we are feeling much more secure.  I am absolutely sure that you will be a highly prudent and a very effective Commission President. The EU needs real leadership. For us, the EU is not only the common market, not only the source of our economic growth and our social welfare, not only our common united instrument to fight climate change. Those benefits which the EU brings to all of us, are becoming even more important when on a national level we are starting to face the stronger challenge of the middle-income trap and long-term economic stagnation.  But besides those benefits, the EU is also for us a basis for our geo-political security and stability. The EU has a very powerful and unique instrument on how to expand the area of security, stability, rule of law and economic growth on our European continent, and this instrument is the new EU enlargement policy. We in Lithuania with the success of our achievements, are the best example of how powerful this instrument is. We are grateful for the European solidarity we received, which was phased  back from the beginning of the 1990s. I would like to use this opportunity to urge you, as the new President of the Commission, to lead an ambitious policy of further EU enlargement, first of all towards the countries of the Western Balkans, and later on also towards the countries of the Eastern Partnership: Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova. The people of those countries deserve our solidarity, and we deserve a peaceful and stable neighbourhood on the European continent. The success of Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova can be a very effective example towards the Russian people and the most effective assistance instruments for positive information in Russia, and I am absolutely sure that the EU under your leadership, Ms von der Leyen, can deliver such an ambitious agenda. I wish you the best of success.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I want to tell you that I liked the progressive and pro-European approach that you presented today in your speech and in the letter you addressed to my group.  I would like to tell you that you will have my vote as head of the Romanian delegation in the Social Democratic Group, but you will also have my vote for a reason that I would like to say to you, namely a hope, the hope that you will fight against discrimination between those who are from Central and Eastern Europe and those from the rest of the European Union , that you will fight for the elimination of the double standard. We have double standards in the Schengen area. Millions of Romanians are humiliated every day at airports in the European Union, citizens of the European Union on the left, Romanians on the right, absolutely unjustified things that President Juncker has sworn about ten times to eliminate during his term of office. He probably wanted to give you this pleasure.  Will you fight against the double standard in terms of agricultural policy? A Romanian farmer, Mrs von der Leyen, receives half of what a farmer in the European Union receives. How can there be real and fair competition in the European Union under these conditions? I believe something else, Mrs von der Leyen, because you said that you have and feel that there must be a spirit of justice in the European Union. I hope that you will fight and provide the necessary funds for the energy and industrial transition regions, because there are hundreds of thousands of families, hundreds of thousands of children, hundreds of thousands of mothers who will be affected, if the regions in industrial and energy transition do not have the necessary support and that this will happen now. I wish you success, Mrs von der Leyen.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, Europe needs a stronger and more united foreign security and defence policy. Lack of a common foreign and security policy renders many other nice decisions meaningless. This is an area where also the Commission needs to show dedication and it is my hope that the Commission will be led by a President who is experienced in the area of security and defence and who has a good understanding of the shortcomings that need to be improved, also in cooperation with NATO. Ursula von der Leyen has contributed to strengthening European defence capabilities and also in the eastern part of the European Union. It is also important that she would become the first woman to hold the office of the President of the European Commission. I will support Ms von der Leyen today because of her experience in security and defence and because she has an understanding and a vision of what is needed to make Europe stronger.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, the Berlin Wall has been down longer than it was ever up. If ever there was a representation of the enduring success of Europe, this is it. More than personalities, Europe is hope; more than bureaucracy, it is justice. Our EU project has inspired people across generations, continents and peoples, but we have to keep working. We are not flawless; our social economy, our free and open approach to trade has raised people out of poverty, but it’s still too hard for too many. We are still too far away. I want my children’s generation to see Europe as the answer as much as it was for my parents and that is why we cannot be silent when our fundamental freedoms are under threat. We can never accept that journalists like Daphne Caruana Galizia are intimidated and killed, as she was 21 months ago today. We must protect the media. We should never let EU citizenship be sold as a commodity. We cannot allow the next generation to have more plastic than fish in their seas. If we cannot find a bold fix for our environment and for our climate now, we never will. Equally, we cannot allow issues like migration to become existential questions that are argued only on short—term lines. We need better border management while remaining fair with those who are in need, firm with those who are not and strong with those who seek to exploit the vulnerable. Our Europe is built on the certainty of our values, on the rule of law and of our freedoms. Without them, there can be nothing else and, Dr von der Leyen, I welcome your assurances and know that you will find us constructive partners in standing up for our European way.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, you are setting a very ambitious course for Europe: halving our CO2 emissions by 2030, and you are absolutely right, it is a matter of life and death. But to win the battle of the climate, the nerve of war is money. Yes, we need a climate bank. Yes, you need an investment fund, you're right. But we have to go further: we need to create a climate budget of 1000 billion each year to finance a real Marshall Plan for Africa, to finance a real research programme and to help all families, all small businesses in Europe to finance the transition. How do you find 1000 billion euros every year without taxing everyone? I think there is an urgent need to tackle European tax dumping. When I was little, the income tax was on average 400% in Europe, 40! It has fallen to 200% today, while profits and dividends are exploding. Only 200% in Europe, while in the United States it is stable, since Roosevelt, at 380%. Because when he arrived, Roosevelt had created a federal tax in just four months. So if we really want to win the climate battle, and I think you want to, my question is simple: can the next multi-year framework generate an additional budget of 1000 billion a year? Can we ask shareholders for an effort, with a tax of only 50%, and without affecting small businesses, without affecting craftsmen? With only 50%, we can make 1000 billions a year. 50%, is it too much to save the climate?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, congratulations, in all honesty. You have done an excellent job here today. A lot of us were very critical, i did in the beginning. But what I heard was a passionate woman with a vision of Europe, who wants to renew Europe, who wants to work with Parliament, who wants to give us the right of initiative.  Of course, Mrs von der Leyen, it plays a role that you are a woman, that you put gender equality forward for the new Commission, that you really want to fight sexual violence and that it must be done that we would always see three men in suits. But above all, you have convinced me with your vision of a real approach to a European asylum and migration policy, with the faster work of the border and coastguard, with a European defence union. I would have preferred to have heard the description European army, I admit honestly, but that step may come later.  Mrs. von der Leyen, you are an amazon. I wish you to hold the reins tightly, to lead Europe over the obstacles and to make us great and strong. Good luck, you can count on our vote.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, much was said. I will focus on three things. Firstly, Ms von der Leyen, I would like to congratulate you for striking the right balance on climate change, on energy policy and on protecting the environment. We have to do more in this area. We have to improve our energy efficiency. We have to reduce CO2 emissions, and we have to do it in a responsible way: by measuring the economic, the social, the environmental impact of the measures that we take; by standing by the side of the people and of the regions that are affected and by strengthening the economy, by strengthening the competitiveness of our economy. You are proposing an ambitious and a realistic approach. I think it is the correct one and I support it.  Secondly, you are proposing a convergence instrument for the euro area. This is needed, but my kind request to you would be to open this instrument also to countries which are not yet in the euro area but which are preparing to join, to allow countries that are preparing to join the euro area to contribute to this instrument, to benefit from it and to be part of the decision making. This would enable their accession to the euro area. It would strengthen the European economy, and it would also improve unity throughout the European Union.  Thirdly, as a Romanian Member of the European Parliament, I would like to say one word, and this is ‘Schengen’. Bulgaria and Romania have been fulfilling the conditions for joining the Schengen area since 2011 and we, the European Parliament, have demanded this several times.
