I would kindly request that you stand by the side of Parliament and that, together with us, you use the tools that you have at your disposal to enable Bulgaria and Romania’s accession to the Schengen area. This is the one topic that the citizens of Bulgaria and Romania are expecting most from the European Union. It will improve the security of the Schengen area, it will not dilute it.  To conclude, I would just like to say: we are a diverse Parliament. We are different. We are not the same. But from what I saw today from the President-designate in her guidelines and in her speech, I think she took all of our positions into account, and this is why I say she deserves the support of Parliament today.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Madam von der Leyen, the European Parliament represents citizens directly. As a Portuguese I represent voters who want a progressive agenda for the future of the Union. In the conversation we had in my group I had some doubts about your level of commitment to what I and the Portuguese delegation committed to our constituents.  However, his written answers and his intervention today were much more convincing. We are therefore in a position to move on to a new stage, to move on to realisation and on the realisation I would like to ask you three questions: what support can we expect from you to advocate an ambitious multiannual financial framework that promotes convergence and cohesion, with answers to the integrated development of the territory? How will you encourage the deepening of the euro area and the creation of a robust European budget capable of protecting the Union from systemic crises? How will you translate the positive commitments you have made into concrete policies that can reconnect European citizens with this wonderful project? Mrs. von der Leyen, it's time for us to get on with the action.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I am fully convinced of Madam von der Leyen’s qualities, but the question is, Madam von der Leyen, not just are you the right person, but are you the right person for this job? There I am not yet fully convinced. Firstly, your proposal for a rule of law mechanism in my view is insufficient. It is weak and too narrow in scope and I also happen to know that it’s actually a proposal from Mr Timmermans that’s supposed to be proposed this week as I had a ‘sneak peek’ at the leaked version. Secondly, I would like to hear you say something about how you are going to fight racism and xenophobia, which is a big problem in the European Union of today.  Thirdly, I’m not so concerned about the right policies – because I endorse the proposals that you’ve made – but the enforcement of those policies, because in the European Union we’re very good at making rules but extremely bad at enforcing them. I’m talking about dieselgate, data protection scandals at Facebook, money laundering – I mean do I need to spell it out? – rule of law and fundamental rights violations in Hungary and Poland and elsewhere.  Now previous Commissions have been very timid. For me the key question is: you are very much the candidate of the Member States, simply because of the procedure that was followed. Now, are you going to be – like previous Commissions – the lapdog of those Member States or are you going to be the pitbull that I would like you to be? That’s what I need to hear.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Chief, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President for the work he has Today we are witnessing a historic moment, because we need to set the course for the next five years in terms of personnel. These are turbulent times, and the turnout alone has shown us that citizens are once again showing more interest in the European Union. But they also expect us to come up with solutions. They expect us to guarantee prosperity, freedom and security – ultimately, a Europe that protects, as the Austrian Presidency of the Council has also had its motto. The European People's Party is the strongest force, and we claim to want to shape. The nomination process can rightly be criticised, and it has already been linked to a loss of public confidence. But the person of the nominees is to be separated from this. It is now a question of quickly restoring this confidence of the citizens. We have to look forward. We need a European Union that is capable of action, and we also need to eliminate deficits. I take you at your word here if you are in favour of legally ensrinking the top candidate system in future. Because we have to take the citizens with us. Above all, we must show them that decisions here are taken transparently at European level. We need visions for Europe. Above all, however, we also need personalities who are prepared to assume this responsibility, who are prepared to take action and to implement it. We have with you a person at the head of the Commission who is assertive. You did not convince me of this only today. However, I believe that a great many other Members have also been persuaded to do so today. That is why you have our full support. And I can also tell you that I believe that you are focusing on the right issues, that there are also issues that have not yet been the focus, such as violence against women. In any case, we will give you our full support on the thematically challenging topics of the future.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to thank mrs von der Leyen for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Although I have been very critical of your nomination, I must acknowledge that you have made a very good speech today, which has also included a great deal of important content. But hand on heart. Europe has already heard a great deal of good talk, and it is more about the concrete projects. It is a question of finally needing tax justice in Europe, of preventing this tax evasion, whether illegal or legal. We are talking about real measures to combat climate change. It is a question of the social pillar in Europe finally becoming and being implemented. And that is where the problem lies, with implementation in Europe. This very often – almost always – fails the member states, and many of them are conservatively governed member states among member parties of the European People's Party. That is why I am concerned. However, it is precisely this implementation that is the crucial thing that Europe needs, and last but not least in terms of fundamental rights and the rule of law, it is particularly important to me that we not only talk about it, but also ensure that, when you are President of the Commission, you too ensure that Europe will not fall to its knees in the future before Orban and Salvini.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, when I see the challenges before us, I am sorry. When I see the potential of the European Union, I console myself.  Since Barack Obama is no longer in office, the free world is without direction, multilateralism is undermined. There's a place to be taken here. Who will be able to fill the vacancy? Europe, of course. All the forces responsible in the European Union will have to be united, first of all for the sake of overcoming the North-South and East-West divides. Moreover, in the face of existential and global threats, starting with climate, we will have to unite the major players such as China, India, the Middle East, otherwise the low-carbon economy remains illusory on a global scale. So you have to dare.  If you are elected and you succeed, what I wish you, no one, at the end of your term, will say thank you. If, however, by misfortune, you were to fail, which I do not wish you, we will send you, but not only you, we will be sent to the devil. Our responsibility is overwhelming, let's assume it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commission President—designate that we need to make sure that Europe reaches each and every European. Europe is not simply or just Brussels or Strasbourg. Europe is each and every one of us. Europe must not be more for some and less for others. We need to make sure that Europe reaches every village, town, boy, girl, student, professional, every citizen through a well thought out multiannual financial framework (MFF) and initiatives. No European should leave their region for an economic reason.  Rules should apply to all. When countries such as Bulgaria fulfil the Schengen criteria, they should indeed be part of it. So, Madam President-designate, will you engage with Member States in the Council that find it difficult to recognise that these criteria have been fulfilled? On the euro area, in order not to be seen as a club for some, if countries fulfil the criteria do you foresee the enlargement of the euro area in the next five years?  Also every business, every entrepreneur and every SME has problems employing prepared and skilled professionals. Shouldn’t we be a little bit more ambitious and take decisive action in upskilling our people? After today, it will be very important that we implement the talk, and I’m ready to walk alongside you in delivering a stable energy market and a forward—looking and modernising industry, one that embraces technology and innovation in order to make sure that our continent is even more competitive.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Thank you for the speech, Mrs von der Leyen. Thank you for listening to the socialist demands for higher ambitions in climate policy.  55 percent reduction in CO2 by 2030. That's fine. However, if we are to achieve this in the European Union, there are also some countries that must be given the opportunity to take the lead. The Nordic countries, with three social democratic governments, are ready to take the lead. In Denmark, the new government has set its target of a 70 percent reduction in CO2 by 2030.  As President of the European Commission, will you ensure that the countries that want to take the lead will have the opportunity? For example, by banning diesel cars and petrol cars, should it be needed? We need that. We need an effective and ambitious green transition if we are to save our planet.  The EU started out as a coal and steel union. I hope that you will help to put yourself at the forefront of the EU becoming a climate union. And if you do, you have my support.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: – Mr President, I really hope that Ms von der Leyen will succeed. I’m not convinced today, but I wish to be convinced by the end of her mandate. If we want to tackle climate change, if we want to define the digital age by European standards, we need to stop disappointing people by always just enforcing the lowest common denominator. We need to surprise them with our ambition and we need to surprise them by supporting the biggest common goal, the biggest common vision that we all have. I agree with many of the points that you raised today, Ms von der Leyen, but we all know that the main hurdle to tackle them does not lie here or in the Commission, but most likely in the Council, and the Council does seem to be the one institution that comes out of this entire ordeal strengthened and I do worry about that. I do worry that we are not willing to talk about the topics and to go there, to really reform the European Union and to go where it hurts. I do think that we need to change this, and this was the vote that the people cast in May – to really reform and renew the European Union so that it works better – and I do think that it needs to work better for its citizens. We need to reform and renew the European Union because otherwise all the important visions that you laid out today will not come about and I do not think that we have the time for that.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, let me say that the comments about democracy made from the now empty benches at the back over there lead me to point out that you, Ms von der Leyen, will only take office if approved by a majority in this Parliament, whereas next week, in Britain, a new Prime Minister will take office without the need for any affirmative votes in parliament. It’s a shocking contrast. But will you get a majority? You are asking this Parliament, after all, to back down from one of its principles – the spitzenkandidat – to which it was strongly attached, so you have had to make serious concessions, movements to what we in this Parliament demand, and you have made a number. What you said on policy is significant. What you said on a right of legislative initiative is important. And, may I add, that what you said on Brexit is important – that you would accept the need for a deadline extension for good reasons. Well, let me tell you, there is a good reason, and that reason is that the British public is changing its mind on Brexit. A majority of people elected to this Parliament recently are against Brexit. Opinion polls are moving. Every opposition party in the House of Commons now, every single one of them, wants a new referendum. Keep that door open.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that the commitment, oral and written, by Ms von der Leyen, to more competitiveness, to a sustainable Europe with more solidarity shows that she saw correctly our programme, but, Ms von der Leyen, you also saw the expectations of Europeans. Europe is in need of urgent action. So it was good to see that you didn’t hesitate in assuming commitments that go towards what citizens expect, which is clear commitment, clear achievements.  We now expect due capacity to compromise and to overcome the blockages from the Council on several issues: on carbonisation, on migration, on euro area reform, on the pillar of social rights. There’s no room for hesitation. Huge challenges lie immediately on our hands, such as the approval of an adequate budget for Europe.  We take your words today, in your written words, with great expectation. Parliament will deliver on its part. The citizens of the EU expect nothing less from us. That means that your pledge on this day is a solemn one. Europeans demand nothing less than five years of redemption of the European project after 10 years of crisis and hesitation. Let us rebuild from now on the Europe of our dreams.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: Candidate Commission President. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this lively discussion. It was constructive, it was controversial, and if there’s any proof needed that democracy in Europe is alive and kicking, you brought that proof in this Parliament today and I thank you for that.  Indeed, it has been mentioned many, many times that we had only two weeks to get to know each other. I’m here. It is a great honour for me to have had the opportunity to present the programme. Of course, we know that a speech is just a speech. It’s limited. But I think you have received today in your offices the guidelines that I laid out to all of us; so written down are details on the topics: a climate-neutral Europe in 2050, a more social and competitive Europe, a Europe that makes use of its full potential, a Europe that has a new push on European democracy and a strong Europe that protects our European way of life.  I am aware, when I listen to you and many, many arguments that there is the feeling of a division between central—eastern Europe and western Europe. We have to overcome that division. I’m full of respect when I think of the effort that the central European and the eastern European countries undertook and undertake to join the European Union, to join Schengen, to join the eurozone, and I think when they meet the criteria, this has to be rewarded.  I’m aware of the fact that there is still a certain division between south and north. I think I’ve elaborated extensively about how we could overcome that, how we find the right balance between responsibility and flexibility and the investment and growth that is needed, and where we will work together. I want to involve and be in closer toucher with this European Parliament and that’s why I support the right of initiative. That’s why I believe we need to find sound ways to anchor the Spitzenkandidat system. I’m convinced we’re able to do that.  I want to build new trust. I want to build a partnership between the European Commission and the European Parliament. I am your natural ally, if I may put it that way, and at the very end, before we’re going to go to the vote tonight, let me end with a saying that comes, once again, from a Greek statesman. He was one of the founders of democracy and I think it’s a wonderful motto for our common work. He says, ‘the secret to happiness is freedom; the secret to freedom is courage’. Let’s have courage together. Let’s be courageous on the European Union. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: in writing. – This week we saw a new direction and a promise of an ambitious programme with guarantees for a better Europe for the next five years. We saw a candidate truly committed to giving European citizens a leading and active role in building the future of our Union. Ursula Von Der Leyen committed herself to many areas of great importance. The one that mattered most in the European elections was climate change and I welcome her practical approach to that. She pledged to reconcile the social and modern market economy in the interests of our citizens. She committed to an action plan to fully implement the European Pillar of Social Rights and different measures in order to achieve a more social, fair and equal European Union. Last but not least, Ursula Von Der Leyen pledged for a fresh new start in migration with a new pact on migration and asylum and the relaunch of Dublin. These are all steps in the right direction. However, migration should be a priority on the Commission’s agenda, where legislative proposals, such as the Dublin Regulation, are enacted and become law. And we, the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, will be pushing for that.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – It is good that the European Commission is getting a new President. I support Ursula von der Leyen. At the same time, it is bad that two Member States of the European Union – Estonia and Romania – are missing for months without their commissioner because of the European Parliament's inability to elect one of the Chairmen of the Commission, so it is not possible to hold the hearings of these Commissioners-designate. Leaving two countries without a commissioner sends the wrong message, as if the Commissioners do not have to ask the people for a mandate, because if the people recognise them for their work and they elect the European Parliament, the country will be deprived of its commissioner's place as punishment. The failure of the two countries to be commissioner is all the more reprehensible as we are facing the debate over the next 7 years of the budget.

name: Marek Paweł BALT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I will vote in favour of Ursula von der Leyen's candidature because I was convinced by her commitments made in the political declaration. These commitments are in line with both my expectations and those of my SLD party and the S&D faction. The President has ensured that the rule of law remains one of the cornerstones of the EU and will be consistently enforced. In addition, it announced the EC's work to mitigate the dangerous effects of climate change, including the financing of these actions, including energy policy, and the introduction of a customs duty on goods from countries that pollute the environment. In its work, the EC also announced measures to enhance security in the EU, including the arms industry and defence policy. Finally, the fact that she confirmed the role of First Vice-President of the EC to an S&D representative convinced me that the promises made would be fulfilled.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to thank you for your presentation and for your initiative to make concrete commitments to the future Commission in areas of particular importance to us and our citizens. The EU has always been a special feature of its particular focus on social policy. A sustainable, comprehensive and just European social policy, which ensures gender equality and the protection of the most vulnerable people, is the cornerstone of which citizens' trust in Europe and its values is difficult to imagine. I am very pleased to see your clear commitment to concrete action to protect the poor and socially vulnerable children by establishing a European Child Guarantee, initiated by us, socialists and democrats. Europe must take concrete action to combat youth unemployment, violence against women and children, ensuring the protection of victims and the responsibility of perpetrators, as well as the full implementation of the Istanbul Convention in all Member States. I very much hope, honourable candidate, that the commitments you have made will soon become concrete proposals that will strengthen the pillar of European social policy and ensure a fairer, safer and more socially responsible Europe.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – As we speak, a new European Commission is slowly forming. The time is ripe for the creation of a new role: that of a EU Commissioner tasked with being the voice of children from across all Member States. As a Union, work has already begun on measures to eradicate poverty and social exclusion, issues that still plague over 20 million individuals who are not yet 18 years of age. Emphasis on child policies, as well as the implementation of a Child Guarantee, among others, are positive steps, but do not go far enough. The current situation still denies children access to basic needs such as healthcare and education. This should not be the case in our flourishing, thriving societies. Dedicated high-level figures are key in our fight against child poverty and exclusion, and will be important allies in the promotion of effective, child-friendly, legislative measures. To this end, I am proud to have signed Eurochild’s petition for the new role of EU Child Commissioner, and I thus urge the future President of the European Commission to take heed of this call for action, and appoint a passionate person with a specific portfolio on children’s rights. We must act now.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – You have been under very serious pressure since the European Council recommended you for this high office. Please don't let yourself be intimidated. It was nominated democratically in accordance with the current EU Treaties, while respecting the rule of law in the EU. To hold you accountable for the top candidate system that does not exist in the treaties is unworthy of you and does not stand on your feet from a legal point of view. With your election today, there is a chance of a new beginning in the application of Article 4.2 of the Founding Treaty, thus ensuring that all Member States are measured by the same standards and respect the constitutional identity of the Member States. To settle our common affairs through dialogue, along the lines of mutual respect, without overturning the fixed powers of the institutions, along the lines of existing rules, not imagined rules.  I also suggest that you open up to Central Europe. Travel to Hungary as soon as possible. Ask questions and you want to understand our reality. Find out firsthand, don't rely on other people's value judgments. Central Europe is now the economic engine of the Union. When reviewing the Union's next seven-year framework budget, it should adapt the draft subscribed by its predecessor to contribute to the continuation of this pace of development. Do not punish good performance, but reward it.  Finally, I ask you to be the threer of our freedom. Think differently, believe in conservative values. It is possible to speak with impunity in order to preserve European civilisation and culture.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: in writing. – Ursula von der Leyen's speech was instrumental in clarifying the vision that the candidate nominated by the European Council has for the next five years. And it will be five structuring years for the construction of Europe's future in the coming decades.  The process of choosing the candidate, which is led by the European Council, was complex and demanding in difficult political circumstances. Being able to make this election in time is essential to continue with the formation of the Commission and the preparation for the new cycle from 1 November.  I welcome the choice of a woman for President of the European Commission and I hope that the composition of the future Commission will be balanced. I am sure that we will have men and women with a clear commitment to the European cause.  Technical competence, political vision and adequacy to the portfolio will be the criteria that will preside over our hearings. And the President-designate of the Commission will have the responsibility to guarantee these conditions a priori a priori.  I follow the priorities set out in relation to combating climate change, completing economic and monetary union, adapting to digital society and economy, eradicating violence against women and institutional reform of the Union.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – Ms Ursula Von der Leyen represents the consensus that for decades has determined the direction of the European Union, namely: (i) the consensus of inequalities between countries, in which the overavites of some are built on top of the deficits and sacrifices of others;  (ii) consensus on levelling below living and working conditions in Europe; job insecurity, instability in the lives of millions of workers, unemployment and underemployment; inequalities between men and women;  (iii) the consensus of large capital and the major powers, which sacrifices the most delighted production systems, the environment and social rights for the profit of multinationals;  (iv) the consensus of privatisation, the attack on public services, threats and sanctions on sovereign states;  v) The consensus of militarism and war.  But these consensuses can count on the opposition of all those fighting for another Europe: the Europe of progress, social justice, environmental protection, democracy, solidarity, peace and cooperation; a Europe that will be fulfilled through the struggle of workers and peoples.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – I warmly support the election of Ursula von der Leyen as President of the Commission. He has strong political experience and the will and ability to build Europe together.  Many people here in the EUROPEAN Parliament are disappointed with the process and, in particular, with the failure to follow the Spitzenkandidat procedure. That does not mean, however, that the candidate should be disqualified. He's an excellent choice. Although the Spitzenkandidae procedure has not succeeded, it should not be rejected either, but developed. Above all, the parties will have to work together much better in the future, as we have seen.  It is pointless for anyone in this House to be offended that the European Council took over in these circumstances. It built a balanced whole that is good to go ahead with. The nomination package pays relatively good attention not only to political power relations, but also, for the first time, to gender equality. It is high time that a woman was in charge of the Commission. If the European Parliament had been united from the outset, the European Council would certainly have heard that message when it made the proposals.  Ursula von der Leyen's candidacy has received strong support from the Member States and has now presented her political policy paper, which takes very good note of the objectives that are important to many political groups here: ambitious climate policy, security, sustainable economic growth and gender equality. Ursula von der Leyen deserves the strong support of this House.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the budget of the Romanian Presidency of the Council (2019/2685(SDR)). I would remind honourable Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this debate, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted. I welcome President Dăncilă, who is here with us in the Chamber and her colleagues in the Romanian Government, and I give the floor to the President.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, honourable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great pleasure to be before the newly elected European Parliament today, in order to present to you the balance sheet of Romania's Presidency at the Council of the European Union, which also contains benchmarks for the common European road that we have before us. As a former member of this forum, I know very well and appreciate the special role that the European Parliament and you have in the European decision-making process. I would like to congratulate you and wish you every success in your mandate. Ladies and gentlemen, it has been important to show that the European institutions work for citizens and, above all, that they produce results that improve their lives and offer prospects for the future. I am pleased to say that Romania has succeeded. We have taken on and assumed this responsibility as a mission to serve citizens and European unity. We felt it necessary for all our actions to be built around cohesion as a common European value. Romania has demonstrated that it can perform successfully against the background of challenges and trends that call into question the Union's determination to progress. We have demonstrated Romania's ability to contribute to the added value of the European Union, which is reflected in the consistent balance sheet we are handing over: 90 completed legislative dossiers and around 2,500 events and organised meetings. At the same time, we facilitated the adoption of 84 Council conclusions on multiple topics of common interest. We wanted to have visible, lasting results through the exercise of this mandate, to which citizens could relate easily and clearly. These results give a genuine identity to our first Presidency, to which I believe we can all relate. For example, I would like to think that when a European citizen has more equitable and transparent access to the labour market, allowing him to better balance his work with his or her private life, he will know that these decisions were taken during Romania's presidency. I also want to believe that the European citizen will feel safer and more protected within the union's borders and because of the efforts of our Presidency. We have managed to make a qualitative leap in this direction. From now on, more effective checks at the external borders will be possible, we will improve the security of identity cards. We have achieved consistent results on all four priority pillars of the Presidency: Europe of Convergence, Europe of Safety, Europe, global actor, Europe of common values. Within the Europe of Convergence Pillar, Romania's Presidency has made intensive efforts to advance negotiations on the future Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, both at the political and sectoral levels. We have also succeeded in finalising negotiations on a considerable number of legislative dossiers aimed at strengthening the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union, and we have secured a long-term vision for the single market. At the same time, the concrete results achieved in areas such as the internal market, in all its dimensions – energy, social affairs or climate change – are elements that will remain landmarks and are already being taken up by our partners in the trio, Finland and Croatia.  At the same time, the challenges of the digital age, of which artificial intelligence, were addressed by the first set of Union conclusions dedicated to this theme. Our Presidency has made an important contribution to the completion of the Digital Single Market through the Digital Single Market Copyright Directive. In all our endeavours, we have sought to place the interests of the citizen at the heart of our vision. Strengthening the social dimension of the Union was thus a priority and the establishment of the European Labour Authority an example of success. From the perspective of the Energy Union, we have adopted the proposal to amend the Natural Gas Directive, which will ensure, for the first time, a uniform and transparent regulatory framework on gas interconnections with third countries. We also aimed to facilitate reflection on the development of a common long-term vision towards climate neutrality. We have adopted the first regulations in the field of emission standards for heavy vehicles.  The safety Europe – the second pillar – was the framework in which we acted to increase security at European Union level, in view of the expectations of our citizens. We have strengthened the mandate of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, and by adopting interoperability legislation, we are sending a clear signal that information systems at European level must complement each other. This is an excellent example of further cooperation between Member States to strengthen the internal security and functionality of the Schengen area, an objective in which Romania wishes to continue to participate fully.  In the area of migration, we have worked to advance negotiations on the reform of the European asylum and migration policy. Even with the continuation of divergences on this issue, we have been able to move forward negotiations on the Return Directive and discussions on the development of temporary commitments. We have also completed negotiations for the functioning of the European network of migration liaison officers. In order to improve the response to cyber-attacks, a sanctions framework has been adopted to respond to cyber attacks. Thus, for the first time, sanctions will be imposed on persons involved in cyber-attacks that threaten the Union or the Member States. Romania will continue to act in this area, pursuing the objective of hosting a European agency specialised in this.  Looking to the external dimension of our work, reflected in the global player Europe Pillar, we have invested consistent efforts to strengthen the profile of an active and effective Union, involved in its neighbourhood and credible by honouring its international commitments. Progress has been made in relevant areas, such as the Western Balkans region, the Eastern Partnership, the Black Sea region. Enlargement is a geostrategic investment in the economic, political and security well-being of the European Union. In the Western Balkans, we managed, against the background of a complex context, to preserve the remarkable, and even historical, developments that were recorded last year, and to maintain the strategic opportunities created for partners in the region, I mean Albania and North Macedonia.  The relevance of our objectives is major in the Europe pillar of common values. The phenomenon of disinformation is indisputable and, therefore, we have forwarded to the European Council the report on combating misinformation and ensuring fair European elections. Another major objective of our presidency was to combat anti-Semitism, xenophobia, hate speech and all forms of intolerance. We hope that these efforts will be continued by our partners in the trio. We believe that promoting equal opportunities and gender is a major objective, which has also been found in the architecture of the new European institutions, the European Parliament and the European Commission.  We have assumed that we will act towards strengthening the European project and, during the six months of our mandate, we have demonstrated that pro-Europeanism must be fuelled by constant action. I have been personally and with all my dedication to the proper conduct of this Presidency and for personal motivation, determined by my deep attachment to the ideal of the European project. I am part of the generation that has matured with this aspiration to the fullness of European integration and its recognition for Romania. I believe that this sense of recognition of the significance that the European Union has for citizens needs to be constantly cultivated through concrete results. Our project must not promote a multi-speed Europe or concentric circles. Romania will continue to promote the common objective of strengthening the European project and will at the same time pursue the completion of its integration. I am referring here, of course, to the full integration of our country into the Schengen area, where we are already acting as a de facto member. We will continue to act in a pragmatic manner to promote the principles of the Sibiu Declaration and remain deeply attached to respect for democratic values and the rule of law. It is important, however, that there are no differences between Member States, fault lines that create different standards for European citizens.  By exercising the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, Romania has confirmed full membership, which shows us the legitimacy of our aspirations to conclude the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. I still firmly believe that our future, for all of us, cannot be imagined any other way, except within a stronger and more cohesive Europe, for which we have worked with enthusiasm, confidence and professionalism over the last six months. I am convinced that the efforts of the Romanian Presidency at the Council of the European Union are a consistent basis for further advancing the European agenda in the coming period and Wish success to the Finnish Presidency of the Council of the European Union. Thank you and thank you for your support in these six months, for your good cooperation, and I am convinced that the rotating presidency held by Romania in these six months will remains both in Romania's memory and in the memory of the European Union as a successful presidency.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s always a pleasure to be in this Chamber and especially today because this morning you have been debating the vision and the expectations for our common Europe for the next five years. Soon you will be voting on that vision so we can fully embark onto the next legislative period, a period that comes in decisive times because of the challenges as well as the opportunities for all of us.  Cooperation with Parliament, with its strong mandate thanks to the highest participation rate in the EU elections in the last 20 years, will no doubt be crucial because together we share responsibility for Europe. Because for Europe to succeed, we must play as a team, guided by the European art of compromise and in defence of the common European interest.  I believe that this was the case not only during the Romanian Presidency that we are summing up here this afternoon, but also it was the spirit of our work during the last five years.  Let me thank Prime Minister Dăncilă for the efforts that Romania took to advance our Europe further. As I said, to achieve results Parliament, the Council and the Commission must work together in the constant pursuit of the general European interest. This is best encapsulated by the fact that to date 354 proposals put forward by this Commission have been adopted, 90% of them by unanimity.  This was not a given. It required hard work and compromise and I am confident that our new Parliament will take an equally constructive approach. In this regard, I would like to congratulate the Romanian Presidency, President Klaus Iohannis, Prime Minister Viorica Dăncilă, the ministers and the brilliant Romanian Ambassador to the European Union, Luminiţa Odobescu, for the excellent work and the many achievements. You invested significant efforts in closing as many legislative files as possible before the last plenary session of the previous European Parliament in April. It was really a political sprint because you managed to close 90 files in the first 100 days of your term, and that’s a testament to your tenacity and dedication.  I am thinking in particular of the strengthening of the European Border and Coast Guard, the Copyright Directive, or the European Gas Directive, which was particularly difficult to conclude and therefore my colleague Energy and Climate Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete also decided to join me today to express also his appreciation for the hard work on this very important piece of legislation.  But I also think about the progress we have made on our Social Agenda, which was a top priority of this Commission from the very beginning. Thanks to the work of the Romanian Presidency we have now higher minimum standards for working parents and carers. We have increased the possibility for men to take up caring responsibilities and we are giving more support to women’s participation in the labour market. We have made contracts and working conditions more transparent and predictable for all types of work, particularly atypical forms of work such as on-demand or part-time work, and less than a year after we made a proposal to establish the European Labour Authority, the Romanian Presidency made this a reality. Regarding the next multiannual financial framework, the Romanian Presidency also did excellent work on the negotiating box and on advancing discussions on the sectoral proposals. Very good progress has been made, including on one of the most critical points, the euro area budgetary instrument. Let us take this forward with determination with the next Presidencies.  We all know how complex the budget negotiation can be, but ultimately it is a matter of political will and we now need to take the decision that will create certainty and stability for the future of our citizens and for our businesses.  Romania has proven that in this challenging year of institutional change in Europe, our Union is breathing with both lungs, east and west. We could certainly feel this at the Sibiu summit on 9 May. This was an important moment for both the European Union and Romania. We could see how brightly the European colours could shine.  The resulting Sibiu Declaration of the 27 EU leaders is a strong message of commitment to each other to build a European future together.  To conclude, let me add, as the Commission has already said in the past, that we believe Romania should be a full member of the Schengen area and I can only call again for the Member States to put Romania in its deserved place in our borderless Europe.  I also would like to say, as the Commission has outlined in the past, that efforts regarding the rule of law and fight against corruption are crucial and must be upheld, because people deserve this.  And my last sentence would be again aimed at, I would say, my personal experience with your country. I visited it many times before and after the big changes in our part of the world, so I can testify to and be a witness of how big the progress is that your country has made over the last few years and therefore your first Presidency should be something the whole nation should be proud of because you did a great job for which I really would like to thank you and I will try to say it in Romanian as well, mulțumesc.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all, on behalf of the PPE Group, allow me to congratulate President Iohannis and you, Prime Minister, and your government, the people of Romania and everybody involved for making your country’s first Presidency a success. You have assumed responsibility at a challenging time for Europe, a period marked by the impending departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union, the ongoing discussions about the future shape of the EU project and institutional renewal, starting with the European elections. Against this background, you have faced high expectations to deliver on legislation, but also to provide guidance on set priorities for the future. During the Romanian Presidency, the EU made good progress on several important issues such as the digital single market, the Gas Directive and the Banking Union. The Commissioner has already talked about some of them.  Together we have also achieved a strong commitment at EU level for the European enlargement perspective for the Western Balkans. We welcome the decision of the Romanian Presidency to keep this important topic on the agenda of the European Union. After a ten-year break, the Sofia summit during the Bulgarian Presidency provided a much—needed tangible roadmap for the European future of this region. We highly value the efforts of both the Austrian and the Romanian Presidency in sustaining and furthering this impetus. It is time to face reality. A weakening of enlargement momentum could easily cause setbacks for the reform agenda in the region and create openings for other third countries to gain greater influence – a situation which, to put it mildly, won’t be in the interests of the European Union. The Romanian Presidency started with the motto ‘cohesion, a common European value’. Indeed, a more cohesive Europe is a stronger Europe.  Many important files have been successfully closed. I would like especially to highlight the agreement on the regulation on the European Border and Coast Guard. Strengthening our border control capacity has been a longstanding priority for the PPE Group. The most important freedom that our citizens enjoy is free travel within the European Union. We can only guarantee this freedom if we secure our external borders to monitor who is crossing them at all times. In regard to my country, Bulgaria, we set a good example on this securing of the external border. We have ensured a high level of protection of our external border also with the help of EU solidarity, which guarantees the security of the whole of Europe. The PPE Group is in favour of a stronger European Border and Coast Guard with increased resources and capacities ready to deploy immediately whenever a country faces disproportionate migratory pressure. We support the reinforcement of Frontex with 10 000 new border guards to help national border enforcement officers. Another key topic was the debate on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the next programming period. The PPE Group wants an ambitious Europe and we need the means to match our ambitions. We cannot expect the EU to deliver on expectations to European citizens if we do not give them the tools to be effective and adapt to the changing world. Although we would have liked the negotiations to be finalised before the European elections, we commend the Romanian Presidency for the good progress achieved in the first half of this year. It is important that we do not reduce the share of the total EU budget allocated to cohesion policy measures post—2020. The European structural and investment funds contribute to improving our infrastructure and closing socioeconomic gaps between regions, but also fight poverty and here Romania – but also all of us – need to do much more by fighting poverty in our Union.  Nevertheless, we would have also appreciated the Romanian Presidency getting better results on the external neighbourhood discussion and improvement on the Schengen enlargement talks. Unfortunately, the Council is still not willing to grant access for Romania and Bulgaria to the Schengen area. The U-turn at the helm of the Council coincided with the negotiations for the appointment of the European Public Prosecutor. The PPE Group strongly supports the efforts to combat fraud affecting the financial interest of the European Union. But of course our Union is not only financial; it is also based on values. Let us not forget that the EU is founded on the shared values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. The rule of law is a fundamental value that we, the members of the PPE Group, care about. Finally, the role of the Presidency is not only to ensure the day-to-day management of the European agenda, but also to set strategic priorities for the future. Here an important success was the EU summit organised in Sibiu by President Iohannis. EU leaders signed the Sibiu Declaration and agreed upon the main steps towards a more united, stronger and democratic Union.  We have received a strong mandate from our citizens. More than 50% of citizens voted in the European elections. Now it’s time for the Finnish Presidency to continue the work and work together with us and the President of the European Commission, who we hope will be elected this afternoon, to realise the ambitious programme presented by Ms von der Leyen in the plenary this morning. Thank you very much again for all your efforts. I am looking forward to the Finnish Presidency.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Prime Minister, Romania has held the Presidency of the Council at a key moment for the future of our Union. It was not an easy task, not only because of the scale of the challenges, with the uncertainty of Brexit, but also because of the short period of time to work. It was a short presidency, because of the European elections, but undoubtedly one of the most fruitful. And that is why I have to congratulate the Romanian Government and I am pleased to be able to welcome its Prime Minister, Viorica Duncil, to this chamber today. The good work of his Government has facilitated numerous agreements, and good work has also done an important job in paving the way for a potential uk exit from the European Union so that the impact is as smooth as possible for both British citizens and other Union citizens. Because that has been the axis of his Presidency: to respond to the needs of the public. The Presidency had as its central theme cohesion, which is one of the expressions of solidarity between citizens and also solidarity between the territories. We know that many regions of Europe are depopulated because young people do not see a future. That is why prioritizing the Europe of convergence has been a success. We want the European Union to take advantage of new technologies and ecological transformation to create new opportunities in all the territories of the Union. In just four months, the Romanian Presidency has managed to close eighty legislative files and ten major institutional agreements. Among the most important successes of this Presidency, let me highlight all the preparatory work and agreements on sectoral proposals for the Multiannual Financial Framework for the next seven years. This Community budget which we must close as soon as the European Commission is launched is fundamental to the now-beginning legislature. Only with a strong budget can we carry out the policies that citizens are waiting for of us and us. The Romanian Presidency has succeeded in promoting measures to strengthen the social pillar, with greater protection of workers through a Directive on fair working conditions and the establishment of the European Labour Authority, issues which were fundamental to us. And another issue that will allow me to move here as one of the great achievements of the last legislature has been the adoption of a Directive to advance the reconciliation of personal and professional life, which includes for the first time paid paternity leave. During these months the Romanian Government has promoted the Europe of solidarity, justice, equal opportunities and gender equality, but also the values of diversity, which are so necessary in the face of those who want to take advantage of fear of the different. That is why I congratulate you on your initiatives to combat racism and xenophobia, as well as all forms of intolerance. Prime Minister, Viorica Duncil, now passes the relay to another Presidency, finland's, which will continue the good work of these months to build a diverse, progressive and just Europe, which is what European citizenship wants.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, Prime Minister Dancilă, Vice-President Šefčovič, the first Romanian Presidency of the Council of the European Union was one of contrasts. At the technical level, Romanian officials and diplomats were able to complete 90 legislative and non-legislative files. That's why I want to congratulate the professionals behind the scenes, those who too rarely receive the word "thank you" for the work done in these (word that is not understood).  The same cannot be said of the political echelon of this presidency. Regrettably, I must say that the current government in Bucharest was far too preoccupied with the problems with the judiciary of its leaders to secure the ambitious presidency. This lack of political ambition has also been matched by anti-European and populist rhetoric from the ruling parties. Fortunately, this rhetoric was drastically sanctioned by Romanian citizens in the vote on 26 May.  Romania has proven that it is much more than the politicians who represent it. Romania means, first of all, citizens who have queued to vote for a European Romania. They certainly deserved more from this opportunity that comes every 14 years. After this Presidency, the Council remains indebted in the political plan on several sensitive and very important dossiers which it has failed to move forward in recent months. I would mention here only three of these.  Firstly, there is a need to unblock discussions on the Multiannual Financial Framework. It is not acceptable to repeat the mistake of the previous financial framework when delayed adoption led to the postponement of national partnership contracts and the final beneficiaries were affected. We need to ensure sufficient resources for agricultural policy and for a cohesion policy that ensures real convergence between the east and west of the continent. We need more Europe in health and education, both in terms of allocating funds and for adopting minimum quality standards at European level.  Secondly, there is a need to unblock the appointment of the Chief Prosecutor of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as soon as possible. The blocking of the appointment was a political one, and the unblocking must also be an act of political will. I expect the Finnish Presidency of the Council to come to the negotiating table with Parliament as soon as possible in order to reach an agreement. Thirdly, we need to move forward on migration and border management issues. The Council, together with the new Parliament and the new Commission, must open a frank and direct dialogue about the future of the Schengen area, a future that leaves no Member State behind and that no longer calls into question the growing practice of internal border controls.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr. Speaker, welcome, Madam Prime Minister, it is always a pleasure to have a head of state or government here. I insist because I know that some people in this House would like to discredit the Council by saying that the Council is not legitimate. You have legitimacy, as do each and every head of state and government, but you obviously have a special responsibility when it comes your turn to hold the presidency. It was the first time for Romania and it is true that, in terms of organisational work, administrative work, we can take our hat off: clearly, Romania has succeeded in its first stint at the head of the Council. It is true that in an election year, when you know that the pressure to complete a certain number of files is enormous, it is rather a successful performance, I want to say. Now, among these files, there are some that are not among the 90 files that have been completed under your presidency and that are emblematic files. The Council itself, at each of its meetings, agitated the asylum and migration file as the file file, the most important file, the one that would suffer no delay, no other priority before it. What do I need to see? It has been four years since the Council has said this, at every conclusion of the Heads of State and Government: migration, migration, migration, migration, border, border and what else do I know. We are still waiting for a position from the Council on the reform of asylum and migration, this package proposed, years ago, by the Commission, and on which this Parliament voted by an overwhelming majority - I said this morning - of five political groups, already two years ago. What have you done to get things done? One of the roles, perhaps less visible, of presidents is to unlock, is to put oil in the gears. Of course not! You have simply acted on the fact that you have decided that the Council will decide unanimously, when this is not justified, and unanimity obviously means that any Member State can block everything. And imagine that there is more than one Member State that is prepared to block everything on this subject. This means that on this subject, which you yourself say is extremely important, you do nothing! Nothing! You, like all the other Member States: from that point of view, none of the 28 is better than the others. Then there is this other aspect, which was mentioned by my predecessor, that of reputation. When a state presides over the European Union, it is absolutely crucial that that state, somewhere, embodies, represents the values of the Union. What show does your government give us? I say your government, I am not talking about Romania. Romania, like Hungary, like Poland, which is often talked about, like all the countries of the European Union, has a place in the European Union. Nevertheless, the government that now runs this country is a government that distinguished itself by brutally suppressing peaceful protests last summer - it was certainly not during the presidency, but nevertheless in your country, it was your government. It is a government that works almost obsessively to bring the judiciary under control in order, of course, to prevent politicians from being convicted of corruption and declared ineligible. It seems that this absorbs most of the political energy of the parties that are in power in your country today. And from this point of view, I note that the many reports made by the Council of Europe, by the Venice Commission but also by the anti-corruption body of the Council of Europe, remain a dead letter. To top it all off, as my predecessor said, you are allowing yourself to block the possible appointment to the post, which is very important in the European Union, as head of the European Public Prosecutor's Office of Laura Codru-a Kovesi, whom we have still not had the opportunity to audition. So no, frankly, the spectacle that your government offers does not honour Europe and, I would say, does not honour Romania. Romania deserves better than that.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Prime Minister, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, during this Romanian Presidency, I have visited Bucharest several times. For the Conference of Presidents with the Council of Ministers, of course, in November, but also last April for a debate on the future of Europe. Each time, we have talked about the great challenges that Europeans and their common civilization will have to face together, on a continental scale: identity and borders, the relocation of the economy, but also data protection, artificial intelligence, the necessary re-industrialisation or the maintenance of our agricultural fabric. So far, on none of these issues has the European Union been able to be effective or even present. Worse, on free trade, it is only accelerating, even recently with Latin American countries or Vietnam. Yet it is the least environmentally friendly and most destructive system in our economies. I say this without, of course, throwing the stone at the Romanian government. It must be said that it has been under heavy fire from the European Commission, which is exploiting the rule of law to impose the joint government of technocrats and judges in the face of the will of the peoples. The reality is that power is now being pagocytized by the Brussels Commission, which combines both the legislative initiative and the monitoring of the application of directives, but also acts as a guarantor of the treaties. However, the presidencies of the Council pass, but the Commission, its bureaucrats and its guidelines remain. Is not the best example of Mr Timmermans, who will no doubt retain his role as a zealous "flag-bearer" against countries that are recalcitrant in Brussels. He who, against Hungary, against Poland, against Romania, tomorrow perhaps against Matteo Salvini's Italy, in short against the nations and against the peoples, will always be at the forefront of attacking and destabilizing governments that nevertheless have democratic legitimacy. In the recent small arrangements to allocate the posts at the head of the European institutions, Eastern Europe has been completely forgotten. Merkel's Germany is, as always, over-represented, in person, or by her supporters or by her straw men. Those who precipitated the enlargement of the European Union to the East now realize that their liberal-libertarian immigrationist ideology is very little shared. Having suffered the yoke of totalitarian communism, the countries of Central and Eastern Europe still know how to develop courageous leaders who refuse to give in to the Commission's demands, particularly with regard to the compulsory distribution of migrants. It is on this issue, and especially that of the reform of the right of asylum, which has become a misguided channel of illegal immigration, that the Juncker Commission has skidded. Fortunately, the Dublin IV reform was blocked in the Council, notably by Hungary and Poland. If the Romanian Presidency, in juxtaposition with the European elections, has not been an opportunity for spectacular progress, let us at least acknowledge that it has not amplified or aggravated the current failures and excesses of the European Union. In view of the pledges it has given to the Socialists and macroist liberals this morning, the appointment of Mrs von der Leyen as head of the Commission would, on the other hand, risk further acceleration, with the Finnish Presidency, towards more federalism, more immigration and less economic protections. The defenders of peoples and nations will therefore be more vigilant than ever to refuse to let the European Union become a machine to destroy Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Dear President, romania's first Presidency of the Council came at a challenging time when the European Union was preparing for the UK's exit and welcoming elections to the European Parliament. Romania has shown that even in such somewhat chaotic circumstances, a good job can be done when there are clear goals and strategies on how to achieve them. The Romanian Presidency will be remembered for a large number of important initiatives and some key agreements with the European Parliament, such as the Gas Directive, the Digital Europe Programme, the European Union's first space programme, the first carbon dioxide emission standards for freight vehicles or the European Coast and Border Guard initiative. While more could have been done in some areas, such as migrant and asylum policy, the Romanian Presidency should nevertheless serve as an example for newer members to play an important and constructive role in this community. Unfortunately, those who should not have seen in the Romanian example the opportunity to restore trust between east and west, old and new members, but in the election of new leaders of the EU institutions further marginalised the European East and new members. It is a bad message mainly to young democracies that strive to reach the democratic and economic standards of the developed West, while respecting both their own and other people's traditions. With this choice of EU leaders, the new members have been re-labelled second-rate, although recently one of them, Romania, has proven that it has both ambitions and knowledge in recent Europe to contribute actively to the development of European policies and this community. I fear that this misunderstanding of the young democracies of Central and Eastern Europe, which have had a different development path, is growing year after year. The old members, it is now quite clear, want to reaffirm their dominance in making strategic decisions for Europe. We can still learn a lot from them, but as partners, not masters. A new Europe must not agree to a vassal relationship. We ask that our identity, our culture, our history and our traditions be respected. We want the European Union to finally become worthy of its slogan "united in diversity" and stop striving for centralisation and uniformity, as this path leads to bigotry and political conflict, which could be devastating for the Union.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mrs Dăncilă and Also Mr Šefčovič, we are discussing the Romanian Presidency's report about two hours before the European Parliament votes on the new proposed President of the Commission. Your presidency has been held in a difficult six months, with European elections, with Brexit moving from one uncertainty to another and social and economic problems acute. You have to your credit that you managed to close several pending files, and this is recorded in the positives of the Romanian Presidency, but the major issues that concern us as the European Union, as the European Parliament, and which also concern the citizens of the Member States have been left outstanding. They didn't move on.  The citizens' demand for a stronger Community budget, which supports and does not weaken cohesion policies, has not moved forward, because regional and social disparities are being reinforced. The social pillar, which remains a label, Mr Šefčovič, after Gothenburg, has not moved forward without binding policies that make it a reality. No steps have been taken to start debating and finally to apply a minimum compulsory European wage everywhere in the European Union. A few hours ago Mrs Ursula von der Leyen promised him again, but five years ago I heard him from Mr Juncker, and we are still at ground zero. Since I do not want to be unfair, I would like to say that positive steps have also been taken, such as the preparation by the Council, under the Romanian Presidency, of sanctions against the aggression of the Turkish leadership, which violates international law. And I am sure that the Finnish Presidency will also continue on this path, because we must support European values when they are threatened by aggressive behaviour by the European Union's neighbours. I also think it is good that, in the area of south-eastern Europe, you have tried to continue the positive example opened by the Prespas agreement between my country – Greece – and Northern Macedonia and I believe that the new Government of Greece, contrary to what it said pre-election, will continue to respect and implement this agreement.  I shall end, Mrs Dăncilă, with an appeal to you, on behalf not only of my political groups but also of many non-governmental organisations – and I know that the Commission also shares this appeal: I ask you now to stop the barbaric transfer, in miserable circumstances, of 70,000 sheep from Romania to the Persian Gulf, because this violates every concept of culture, which must respect both human and animal rights.

name: Jake PUGH
text: – Mr President, we in the Brexit party like to expect that we’re going to be making the most unpopular speeches in this place, but I think the contributions from the gentlemen from Renew and the Greens have set a pretty high bar: trying to tell you, Madam Prime Minister, how you should be running your own country. Pretty remarkable. But in the context of the outgoing Romanian Presidency, I would like to congratulate in particular Simona Halep on her stunning performance at Wimbledon on Saturday. It was a performance of poise, power and precision and, most importantly, she will have inspired millions of young girls at home and abroad to participate in sport. Collective Romanian pride in her performance stems in part because it is a strong expression of identity and nationhood. Note I said ‘nationhood’, not ‘nationalism’. I was going to make the point to the Lib Dems but I note they’re not here. Romanian flags flew proudly over the weekend from Bucharest to Baia Mare, but I didn’t hear one rendition of the EU anthem. Sport can do more than almost anything else to bring people together. Tragically, in contrast, whatever the intentions of the European project, it divides more than it unites. But at the conclusion of the Romanian Presidency, and coming back to the four pillars, you mentioned, Prime Minister, let’s judge it against its own priorities. Just two. You talked about convergence through economic growth and employment. Economic growth in the EU is now at the lowest it is been for the last three years. Youth unemployment in Romania is 16%; it is 20% in France; 30% in Italy and Spain; 40% in Greece. Entire generations of young people, their lives laid waste at the altar of the European ideal. Secondly, developing the EU defence capability. So, having refused to pay for its share of European defence, the EU now wants its own army. That can only encourage those who wish to harm us and will undermine the security of Europe through NATO. For those of you who will remain in this place when the UK leaves very shortly, you may look for more from the Finnish Presidency, but I suspect that will be a triumph of hope over expectation. So rather than celebrating the efforts of the Romanian Presidency, let’s celebrate the success of Simona Halep, a real symbol of Romanian pride, a far better use of our time and less damaging to the economy and security of Europe.

name: Jake PUGH
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members of this Parliament for highlighting the challenges which we have to confront when we are going to build and strengthen our common and undivided European Union. I very much agree with the need to make more progress on our social pillar and I’m sure that the next Commission will take very seriously all questions related to the minimum wage or to the improvement of our social standards across the European Union, as it was suggested by Ms García Pérez. I would also like to thank the Members for highlighting the successes of the Romanian Presidency, as Mr Kovatchev did, especially in the listing all the important files which have been concluded thanks to the professionalism of Romanian negotiators and Romanian diplomats and ministers.  I would also like to recognise the good cooperation we had with the Romanian Presidency in completing and concluding all very important files on better tackling climate change.  A lot has been done, in record time. The Romanian Presidency was starting at the beginning of the very crucial transitional year, where the time for real legislative work was very, very short, but it was well spent, it was done very professionally. For that, I really would like to thank you and highlight the fact that you managed this very demanding work despite the fact that it was your first presidency. I know how much each new Member State gains in the form of experience, in the form of establishing good working contacts with other partners in the EU and with European institutions, and therefore I believe that it was not only investment into the future of the European Union but it will also translate into even more professional work by the Romanian civil service and I’m sure that all that experience and all that work, which was invested in Europe, will also be felt back in Romania.  Mr Prime Minister, thank you very much and congratulations on your excellent first presidency.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – I want to thank everyone for their appreciation. Indeed, Romania held the rotating presidency at a challenging time, which the European Union has not had before. I am referring to the Brexit process, I am referring to the fact that it was the European Parliament elections, which has caused all the work of the rotating presidency to take place in the first part, in the 100 days. It's true, we wish in 100 days we'd closed 100 files. We have only closed ninety, but I believe that Romania has taken steps forward and, indeed, Mr Vice-President, for Romania is a cause for celebration. It is a cause for celebration for the whole people, for all those who believe in Romania and those who want to represent Romania with dignity. It is true that we could have done more things, that we would have liked to have done more things, but it is not easy to build consensus between 28 Member States where the priorities are different. We know that during the rotating presidency we have to be a very good mediator and a facilitator of consensus, and I believe that this has done Romania and managed to achieve these results. With regard to the multiannual financial framework, it is true, I am convinced that the new Parliament, that the European institutions will achieve results in terms of financial projection. But also in this chapter Romania has taken important steps, also with regard to cohesion policy, and with regard to the common agricultural policy. Projects can continue, but, of course, for a project to have the efficiency we all want, it must be matched by an appropriate financial projection. We chose the main theme - cohesion - because we believe that cohesion is needed. We need unity at European Union level, because only if we show cohesion will we be able to take important steps and maybe take bigger steps on our own, but I am convinced that we will take good steps together. That is why I believe that cohesion is very important, not only during the rotating presidency, but cohesion must guide the actions of the European institutions in the future. Mr. Tudorache, I'll answer you specifically. It was not Romania's officials and diplomats who did, they carried out the presidency. The Presidency was led by the Romanian government. At each meeting, the Minister presided over the work, it was a very good cooperation, for which I congratulated our experts, all those who were involved, all those who really acted for Romania and not against Romania.  A few minutes earlier someone asked me: "Do you think that Romanian MEPs will be united in bringing an extra image to Romania?" Now I leave disappointed, with people like you, we will not bring an addition to Romania. Let's solve the problems at home, don't come with them to the European Parliament, because these things don't add to our country's image. Moreover, everyone congratulated the Romanian presidency. There have also been things that some MEPs thought we could do better, but they did not criticise and you will not see here in Parliament a lot of MEPs who criticise their country. But you did it when the Vice-President of the European Commission said that Romania has a cause for celebration. Moreover, I want to tell you that the European Union, research inga little ahead, has no powers on health, education and culture. It comes with projects. So you also talked about three elements that you don't know. And I think you know nothing about the achievements of the Romanian Presidency. You do not know that during the presidency a country cannot intervene. He has to be a facilitator of consensus. That is what Romania has done, and I would have been glad if this project, which is particularly important for my country, this rather important and very important project for all European citizens, would have found consensus, because we found consensus at the European Commission, we found consensus at the European Council, we found consensus among many MEPs, we found consensus in the President of the European Parliament , and we all understand that the European Union is at a turning point and, if we do not act together, we will not make good sense of European construction.  We listened to all the advice and, together, we achieved these things. I believe that they must guide us over the next period, to bring added value. Citizens don't need scandal. Citizens need things to help them in their daily lives, policies closer to them, not things to bring into the public space, believing that we have more political significance. Mr. Lamberts, I'm sorry he left, on the logistics side, I liked this "Down with the Hat", I think Romania deserves this. For us all the dossiers were important, and in relation to GRECO, we look at every point at GRECO, but I think we need to to look at Belgium, the country of which it is a part. There are 15 recommendations, of which he has implemented only one. We must let GRECO not interfere and the magistrates intervene. If, indeed, we want independence of justice, we need magistrates to find consensus, not implement it ourselves.  Finally, I want to thank everyone. I want to thank all those who trusted us, because your trust was not only trust in the Romanian government, it was not only trust in our experts, in our diplomats, it was trust in a country that held for the first time the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, a country that gave its first examination in this position and which I believe , and I saw that many of you consider the same, that it passed with flying colors. Thank you once again for your involvement, for your support, for the way we have cooperated. I wish, once again, success to the new Parliament, and I hope that you will have here, in this very important European forum, in which we have been active for nine years, to be successful, because your success is the success of all European construction.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, the debate is closed. I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have spoken, Vice-President Šefčovič, President Dăncilă, all the ministers who are present and their collaborators, congratulations on your work, on your commitment, and tomorrow we will open a new six months. Thank you, the debate is closed, the sitting is suspended until 6.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would like to express my appreciation to the Romanian Presidency for its valuable presidency in recent months in the Council of the European Union. It is very important in my opinion that the Romanian Presidency has taken a number of actions aimed at further strengthening the EU's internal security architecture, including the implementation of the renewed EU Internal Security Strategy. Poland was an active participant in this process, taking part in discussions on the development of individual initiatives aimed, inter alia, at increasing the capacity of Member States to prevent and combat serious crime and terrorism. The Romanian Presidency's action on border protection, in the light of the ongoing migration crisis, was aimed at reaching an agreement on a draft revision of the European Border and Coast Guard Regulation (ESGiP) and the Return Directive. Within the internal dimension, the Romanian Presidency continued its work to make progress on the reform of the Common European Asylum System (WESA).
